data:

6) On the submission of pleader for accused matter has been posted to "decide application for Discharge u/s 239 Cr PC )
Question
1) Can in Summons case application u/s 239 is maintainable or it to be dismissed as application u/s 239 Cr P C only applies to Warrants cases

									Dear client, 

Discharge application under section 239 of Crpc can be filed even before the charges are set against a person if the judge views that there is no sufficient ground available for implementing the proceeding against the accused. headline: Reply to a Rejoinder
data:
To a Plaint, the defendant files Written Statement, to which the Plaintiff has the option of filing a Rejoinder. What if the Defendant wants to reply to this Rejoinder. And what is the name given to it.

Call me will discuss
Advocate Irfan Shaikh 										
									 
									
									Additinal reply of plaint or written statement no tike limit on next hearing day u cn file

									He will get chance to reply . click										
									 
									
									Dear client, 

The reply to rejoinder is known as surrejoinder. You may file the surrejoinder within 2 weeks from the date of rejoinder or within the time the court permits. The maximum time limit to file surrejoinder on extension is 30 days from the rejoinder.

headline: Inappropriate notice period
data:
I have issue regarding serving notice period.
When i joined the company it was 45days, but later they changed it to 90 days on an e-mail without our consent.
Now when i Resigned they are asking me to serve 90 days notice period but i am saying that i never agreed to it.
They are saying that i never sent a mail declining the 90day notice period mail hence i should server 90days. Is there a way out.
Please help.									
									 
									
									Issue labour notice than leave company asking them to clear dues										
									 
									
									Dear client, 

The mail sent to you informing you about the 90 days notice period is a notice mail giving you information or bringing the change to your notice and not a mail asking for your opinion or consent upon it. It is a rule of the company, if you had any objection you should have raised it as soon as it was brought to your knowledge. Your silence is an implied consent to the change, so you are bound by it. 

Thank you, hope it helps.

headline: Unauthorised construction in an undivided share
data:
Both persons have an undivided share in the ratio of 40% and 60%. The person having 40%, erected an unauthorised construction in prime front portion without partition deed nor any agreement with the other share holder. In this case, what action can I take. Can police have any role in it.
Please advice									
									 
									
									No police does have any role
Please go for Suit for Permanent Prohibitory Injunction and get stay on same date then file Application for partition before Tehsildar concerned under sec 105 oj Jammu and Kashmir Revenue Act or Suit for partition before court										
									 
									
									Dear client, 

The police have no role here. You can approach the court for the unauthorized construction in the undivided share. Construction cannot be done just because the ratio between the 2 persons is decided, both parties must sign an agreement mentioning the extent and area of their share. As there is no agreement you have right to stop the construction, you can apply for an immediate stay order to stop the construction. 

Thank you, hope it helps.

headline: Marriage certificate for Christian couple married 30 yrs ago
data:
Case: A Christian couple married in Delhi about 30 years ago, and received a marriage certificate from their church in Delhi under the Indian Christian Marriage Act, 1872. They have since been residing and have all their ID proof of Noida, UP. As per the visa process for travel, they are required to submit a marriage certificate. 

Questions:  
1. If Christian marriage certificates are considered valid under the above Act, does the couple need to have a government issued marriage certificate too, or will the church issued marriage certificate suffice for the visa process? 

2. If they do require the government issued marriage certificate, would the same be available at the local marriage registrar’s office as the marriage was solemnized in Delhi, and as per the Act, the details of all marriages conducted by the church need to be registered at the registrar’s office?  

3. If they they do need the government issued marriage certificate and the church issued marriage certificate will not suffice and is not available at the local marriage registrar’s office, then which location should the couple apply for issue of a marriage certificate, since they got married in Delhi, but have been residing with ID proof of Noida?									
									 
									
									The marriage certificate issued by a Registered Church is valid document for proof of solemisation of Christian marriage. It can be submitted as proof during application for passport as well as Visa.
Though, the marriage registered under the office of Registrar of Marriage is universally accepted.

The certificate of marriage can be obtained from either of these two places, since the law says that-:
A certificate of marriage can obtained after registration, from the place where the marriage was solemnised
Or
At the place where both or either of the spouses lives.
You may contact me for professional consultation through call or whatsapp to discuss in detail as well as for procurement of such certificate from Delhi or Noida, from wherever you wish to have.										
									 
									
									1 Yes it is required  . 2 yes it can be  at local registrar of marriage . but submit that proof of marriage as in Church certificate . 
3Any Registrar in India can register . click

Christian marriage certificate is enough
if it is registered by you or by that church in the registrar office theynyou can have the same now
visit the marriage registrar office for searching and getting that marriage certificate from the registrar officer
Advocate, A.P.Loganathan, Madras High Court
Please click LIKE for encouraging/appreciating me
For more clarification contact me, getting details from path legal or Google site
										
									 
									
									In India, the Christian Marriage Act, 1872, governs the solemnization and registration of Christian marriages. Here are the answers to your questions:

    Validity of Church-Issued Certificate:
        The church-issued marriage certificate under the Indian Christian Marriage Act, 1872, is valid for legal purposes and is generally accepted as proof of marriage. However, for certain legal processes, including the visa application, authorities may require a marriage certificate issued by the government.

    Government Issued Marriage Certificate:
        In addition to the church-issued certificate, the couple may need to obtain a marriage certificate issued by the government. This is often available from the office of the Registrar of Marriages where the marriage was originally solemnized or registered.

    Registrar's Office Location:

        Since the marriage was solemnized in Delhi, the details of the marriage should be available at the Registrar of Marriages in Delhi. The couple can approach the Registrar's office in Delhi to obtain a government-issued marriage certificate.

        However, if they have been residing in Noida, UP, they may also consider approaching the local Registrar of Marriages in Noida for information on the procedure to obtain a duplicate or certified copy of the marriage certificate. The local registrar may guide them on the process, and they may need to provide information such as the date of marriage and other relevant details.										
									 
									
									Dear client, 

The church issued marriage certificate is a valid document, but it is better to have a government marriage certificate as it sufficient for all purposes. You can get your government marriage certificate issued from the local registrar’s office. You can get the certificate in any place by providing your church marriage certificate.

12. Duties of conciliation officers.- (relevant section 12(2) of ID Act)

(1) Where any industrial dispute exists or is apprehended, the conciliation officer may, or where the dispute relates to a public utility service and a notice under section 22 has been given, shall hold conciliation proceedings in the prescribed manner.

(2) The conciliation officer shall, for the purpose of bringing about a settlement of the dispute, without delay, investigate the dispute and all matters affecting the merits and the right settlement thereof and may do all such things as he thinks fit for the purpose of inducing the parties to come to a fair and amicable settlement of the dispute.

(3) If a settlement of the dispute or of any of the matters in dispute is arrived at in the course of the conciliation proceedings the conciliationofficer shall send a report thereof to the appropriate Government 1 or an officer authorised in this behalf by the appropriate Government] together with a memorandum of the settlement signed by the parties to the dispute.

(4) If no such settlement is arrived at, the conciliation officer shall, as soon as practicable after the close of the investigation, send to the appropriate Government a full report setting forth the steps taken by him for ascertaining the facts and circumstances relating to the dispute and for bringing about a settlement thereof, together with a full statement of such facts and circumstances, and the reasons on account of which, in his opinion, a settlement could not be arrived at.

(5) If, on a consideration of the report referred to in sub- section (4), the appropriate Government is satisfied that there is a case for reference to a Board, 2 Labour Court, Tribunal or National Tribunal,] it may make such reference. Where the appropriate Government does not make such a reference it shall record and communicate to the parties concerned its reasons therefor.

(6) A report under this section shall be submitted within fourteen days of the commencement of the conciliation proceedings or within such shorter period as may be fixed by the appropriate Government: 3 Provided that, 4 subject to the approval of the conciliation officer,] the time for the submission of the report may be extended by such period as may be agreed upon in writing by all the parties to the dispute.]

									In DLSA generally young lawyer render their service who lack experience and knowledge. Nominee has only right to receive the property and nominee is bound to handover/pay the received amount to legal heir of deceased. so the opinion of young lawyer is not correct. Father is not the class-1 legal heir so is not entitled to any money or property of deceased son. Being nominee father can only receive but is bound to hand over the same to class-1 legal heir of son. Mother, wife and children are class-1 legal heir. If husband has left any WILL or hand written note bequeathing his property then property shall devolve accordingly. Even on filing succession certificate all concern persons and other parties too can file their objections and can oppose your petition. Generally it takes one to two years in one succession certificate. 										
									 
									
									Dear Madam,
Process for getting succession certificate simplified
in case of death of a person without leaving a will, court may grant succession certificate in order to realise securities or debts of the deceased. A civil court issues succession certificate to the legal heirs of a deceased person.
It is required to establish the authenticity of the heirs. Also to authorize them to get assets or securities transferred in their names. Not to forget that assets comes with liabilities as such it also enables inheritance ofdebts. This is issued on the application from the beneficiary, to court as per laws of inheritance. It is necessary, though may not be always sufficient, to release or transfer the assets. For these letter of administration, no-objection certificates and death certificate is also required.
Application: As discussed earlier also, a petition is required to be filed with the competent jurisdiction where the assets are located.
Details: The application requires details like
– name of petitioner
– relationship with deceased
– names of all heirs of the deceased
– time, date and place of death
Also a copy of the death certificate is required to be produced.
Fees: A fixed percentage of the value of the estate is levied as fee for issuance of the certificate by the court. This fee is to be paid in the form of judicial stamp papers of the said amount. Only after this a the certificate is issued. Also, the lawyer will also charging their fees.
Process: The notice in the newspapers for a given period (generally 45 days) is issued by the court. In case where no one contests the petition on or before the expiry of given period, the court sanctions the order for issuance of succession certificate.
If the petition is not contested, the court usually issues a succession certificate in five to seven months.
==============================================================
Section 372 in The Indian Succession Act, 1925
372 Application for certificate. —
(1) Application for such a certificate shall be made to the District Judge by a petition signed and verified by or on behalf of the applicant in the manner prescribed by the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (5 of 1908) for the signing and verification of a plaint by or on behalf of a plaintiff, and setting forth the following particulars, namely:—
(a) the time of the death of the deceased;
(b) the ordinary residence of the deceased at the time of his death and, if such residence was not within the local limits of the jurisdiction of the Judge to whom the application is made, then the property of the deceased within those limits;
(c) the family or other near relatives of the deceased and their respective residences;
(d) the right in which the petitioner claims;
(e) the absence of any impediment under section 370 or under any other provision of this Act or any other enactment, to the grant of the certificate or to the validity thereof if it were granted; and
(f) the debts and securities in respect of which the certificate is applied for.
(2) If the petition contains any averment which the person verifying it knows or believes to be false, or does not believe to be true, that person shall be deemed to have committed an offence under section 198 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (45 of 1860).
56 [(3) Application for such a certificate may be made in respect of any debt or debts due to the deceased creditor or in respect of portions thereof.]

headline: Consequential benefits of illegal order of retiring employee before e
data:
An employee give three months notice for seeking voluntary retirement from service of the Bank. The bank retires him before expiry of notice period. There is no express powers given to Appointing authority in service regulation.  Aggrieved employee files cwp in high court. The court stays order of retiring employee before expiry of notice period. The employee rejoins and subsequently retires on superannuation.  If court holds the said order illegal then will employee gets salary for period when he remained out of service?									
									 
									
									Dear client, 

Yes, the employee will get a salary for the period he remained out of service if the court holds the order to be invalid. If there is any disturbance to the employee by the action of the employer in continuance of work, the employer is liable to pay salary and the employee is entitled to all benefits as in service for that period. 

Thank you, hope it helps.

Please approach the following authority or similar authority in a state


The Office Commissioner of Labour
Karmika Bhavan, Dairy Circle, 
Bannerghatta Road, Bangalore-29.
=======================================================================
Section 12 in The Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
12. Duties of conciliation officers.- (relevant section 12(2) of ID Act)

(1) Where any industrial dispute exists or is apprehended, the conciliation officer may, or where the dispute relates to a public utility service and a notice under section 22 has been given, shall hold conciliation proceedings in the prescribed manner.

(2) The conciliation officer shall, for the purpose of bringing about a settlement of the dispute, without delay, investigate the dispute and all matters affecting the merits and the right settlement thereof and may do all such things as he thinks fit for the purpose of inducing the parties to come to a fair and amicable settlement of the dispute.

(3) If a settlement of the dispute or of any of the matters in dispute is arrived at in the course of the conciliation proceedings the conciliationofficer shall send a report thereof to the appropriate Government 1 or an officer authorised in this behalf by the appropriate Government] together with a memorandum of the settlement signed by the parties to the dispute.

(4) If no such settlement is arrived at, the conciliation officer shall, as soon as practicable after the close of the investigation, send to the appropriate Government a full report setting forth the steps taken by him for ascertaining the facts and circumstances relating to the dispute and for bringing about a settlement thereof, together with a full statement of such facts and circumstances, and the reasons on account of which, in his opinion, a settlement could not be arrived at.

(5) If, on a consideration of the report referred to in sub- section (4), the appropriate Government is satisfied that there is a case for reference to a Board, 2 Labour Court, Tribunal or National Tribunal,] it may make such reference. Where the appropriate Government does not make such a reference it shall record and communicate to the parties concerned its reasons therefor.

(6) A report under this section shall be submitted within fourteen days of the commencement of the conciliation proceedings or within such shorter period as may be fixed by the appropriate Government: 3 Provided that, 4 subject to the approval of the conciliation officer,] the time for the submission of the report may be extended by such period as may be agreed upon in writing by all the parties to the dispute.]

data:
My mother has a self earned property of 2 cents. My brother also has 2 cents by separate document. a house is there in  whole 4 cents. I, mother, father and brother are jointly living therein.

what kind of document to execute for this?									
									 
									
									Better make her a registered will by her give property to u and brother but u will not disturb her til her death make it registered will										
									 
									
									According to the Transfer of Property Act 1882, a property transfer with condition is a type of conditional transfer, where the transfer of property depends on the fulfilment of a condition imposed by the transferor1. The condition must be lawful, valid, and possible to perform.
In your case, your mother wants to transfer her self-acquired property of 2 cents to you, subject to the condition that you and your brother should not disturb her to live in the house till her death. This is a valid condition, as it does not violate any law or public policy, and it is possible to comply with.
The kind of document that you need to execute for this property transfer with condition is a gift deed. A gift deed is a legal document that records the voluntary transfer of property from one person to another without any consideration or payment. A gift deed must be registered with the sub-registrar of the area where the property is situated, and it must be stamped according to the law.
To execute a gift deed, you need to follow these steps:
•	Draft a gift deed that contains the details of the property, the transferor, the transferee, and the condition attached to the transfer
•	Get the gift deed signed by your mother as the transferor, and by you as the transferee, in the presence of two witnesses.
•	Get the gift deed registered with the sub-registrar of the area where the property is located, by paying the registration fee and stamp duty as per the state laws.
•	Get the gift deed attested by the sub-registrar and obtain a certified copy of the same.
Once the gift deed is executed, your mother will transfer her property of 2 cents to you, and you will become the absolute owner of the property, subject to the condition that you and your brother should not disturb her to live in the house till her death. If you or your brother violate the condition, the gift deed may become void and the property may revert back to your mother.

headline: Validity duration  of the Aggrement to sale -  reigstered un-register
data:
Sir / Madam,

I'm planning to buy a flat.  Registration process is in stop condition, due to transition of the area from Gram Panchayat to Municipality is undergoing where the flat lies .  As the government process is taking time  and it has been more than an year for now after the token has been paid.  

The developer (JV  project land ower gets few flats in leu of his land) is ready to give possession after paying the full amount, and has agreed to execute a notarized document on Rs. 500 /- Stamp paper.

So my question 

1) Whether such  un-registered document is valied till the final sale deed gets registered ?
2) Whether Rs. 500 /- Stamp paepr is sufficient to record the details.
3) What should be the title of the document - whether Aggreeement to sale  or MOU or any thing else which you can suggest , which would have more legal weightage.
4) In the above case how long the above aggreement to sale would be valid - I meant if the governemt would take another 2 yrs or so , will this document bind him to  execute the sale deed in favour of me or my legal heir or whoever I direct to register.
5) Taking possession with full payment with documentation of the agreed on the stamp paper would be safe  or not .
6)  What are the thing that would be extreme important to mention in the above executed document so that  finally it should be suitable to get it registered as sale deed for my title.
7) Any advise or suggestion in this regard as It has been long waiting for 1yrs not getting the registration process started and have paid the token advance.
8) Is un-registered agreement to sale is valid ?

Thanking you Sir / Madam.									
									 
									
									Plz contact in person, either through call or whatsapp or visit my office to discuss the entire issue in detail.
There are many legal implications in purchasing flats in Delhi region, since most of the areas are having recognised colonies.

										
									 
									
									Purchasing a flat in India typically involves a sequence of steps, including scrutinizing property documents, disbursing stamp duty and registration fees, executing a sale deed, and transferring the title. Presently, due to an administrative transition from Gram Panchayat to Municipality jurisdiction, the registration of new sale deeds has been suspended. In this context, you're considering purchasing a flat using an unregistered document executed on a Rs. 500/- stamp paper.

Regarding the validity of such unregistered documents, they lack legal force in conveying property titles and cannot be the basis for ownership privileges, including tax benefits and home loan eligibility. They may merely indicate an understanding or receipt of payment without imposing legal obligations or conferring legal rights.

As for the adequacy of a Rs. 500/- stamp paper, it is unlikely to be sufficient for a property transaction considering the variance in stamp duty based on state regulations, property value, and other transaction specifics. Insufficient stamping can incur penalties or legal repercussions.

In terms of the document's nomenclature, an "Agreement to Sell" would possess more legal weight than a "Memorandum of Understanding" (MOU) due to its binding nature, which compels the completion of sale upon payment. Conversely, an MOU merely outlines the intent to negotiate in good faith without creating binding obligations.

Regarding the Agreement to Sell's duration, its validity is usually defined within the agreement itself, which prescribes the transaction's completion timeframe. If unforeseen circumstances—like government delays—arise, parties are often bound to the agreement terms, provided extensions or renewals are stipulated within the agreement, ensuring that it doesn't lapse by default due to such delays.

Taking full payment and possession under an unregistered document is risky, as it doesn't guarantee legal ownership or the benefits thereof. It opens up potential disputes or claims and disqualifies you from tax deductions, loans, or property insurance. Additionally, any complications or insolvency involving the seller could result in financial loss or property disputes.

In preparing for eventual registration, the unregistered agreement should explicitly include comprehensive details about the parties involved, property specifics, payment terms, possession details, title clarity, registration specifics, indemnities, and arbitration clauses, along with all pertinent annexes like tax receipts or no-objection certificates from authorities.

While waiting for over a year for the registration process to begin, having paid a token advance, you are advised to seek expert legal advice, confirm the property and seller's credibility, document the sale terms carefully, pay due stamp duty and fees, and record all transactions and communications diligently. Once registration resumes, promptly finalize the sale deed to secure your ownership rights.

Lastly, it's crucial to note that while an unregistered Agreement to Sell documents the intent and payment, it lacks the enforcement power of a registered deed for actual property title transfer and the associated owner's benefits. Legal consultation is highly recommended to navigate these complexities and to safeguard your interests.

headline: Special Leave Petition challenging NCDRC judgement

Article 136 of constituion provides for grant of SLP against order of NCDRC and they can be challenged by way of SLP only if it is passed by commission of original jurisdiction. A special leave petition has to be filed at supreme court within 90 days from the date of judgement of the high court or within 60 days at high court for order rejecting grant of certificate of fitness for appeal to supreme court. Hence, in your case SLP will not be maintainable.

									Dear Sir,
Please understand that if you belongs to fourth generation then only you will get rights over the property by birth otherwise not entitled see the definition as follows: 
===================================================================================================
What does the grandparent's property law in India state? Does the grandson own the right to the property?
All property's owned by a Hindu person devolves onto his class one legal heir's. 

Now to the specific scenario's in ur example (for sake of convenience I'm presuming your grandfather has only one legal heir)

Senario1: The property is self acquired by your Grandfather, in such case upon his demise intestate (without a will) the property would devolve upon ur Father and not you. In case your father passes away before your grandfather then in such case it would devolve upon you, your mother and ur siblings equally.

Scenario 2: the property in question is self acquired by ur grandfather father ( ur great grand farther) - would devolve same as scenario 1.

Scenario 3: the property in question is self acquired by ur grandfather grand father ( ur great great grand farther) - would devolve same as scenario 1.

Scenario 4: the property in question is self acquired by ur grandfathers great grand father ( ur great great great grand farther) - then in such a case you would be entitled to the property by birth as it becomes ur ancestral property.

To give you more clarity on the concept of Ancestral Property's : any property which passes undivided down 4 generations of male lineage is called ancestral property. The right to such property acquires at birth unlike other laws of inheritance where right arises upon the death of the the owner.

Hope this brings some clarity to your question and your sense of entitlements.
Meaning of ancestral property  in India-An ancestral property means a propertywhich is devolved upon heirs by the 3 generations above them; father, father's fatheror father's fathers' father. ... That means when a coparcener acquires his share inancestral property than he can make a will to that share and bequest it.
Meaning of ancestral property in India-An ancestral property means a property which is devolved upon heirs by the 3 generations above them; father, father’s father or father’s fathers’ father. It passes to the next three generations.
Meaning of will-A will means a document in which a person specifies the method to be applied in management and distribution of properties after his death.
The basic principle involved is that the property should be four generations old. The right to use and acquire property is accrued by persons through birth itself. The division of property is per stripes i.e. that share of one generation is calculated first than the share of successive generations is subdivided according to share of their predecessor. These basic elements are for governing majorly the Hindus.
If A inherits property, whether movable or immovable, from his father or father’s father, or father’s father’sfather, it is ancestral property as regards his male issue. If A has no son, son’s son, or son’s son’s son in existence at the time when he inherits the property, he holds the property as absolute owner thereof, and he can deal with it as he pleases . A person inheriting property from his three immediate paternal ancestors holds it, and must hold it, in coparcenary with his sons, sons’ sons and sons’ sons’ sons but as regards other relations he holds it and is entitled to hold it, as his absolute property.”[1]
Now answer to the question is that that will to ancestral property is not entirelyillegal. That means when a coparcener acquires his share in ancestral property than he can make a will to that share and bequest it. However will shall be executed after the death of the testator and if the coparcener before acquiring a share makes a will than that will be illegal. Share in ancestral property will be inherited by coparceners. So he can make a will to his share in ancestral property.As whatever he acquires is his share now and he can dispose his assets according to his wishes.
Surender Kumar vs Dhani Ram CS (OS) No.1737/2012 decided on 18th January, 2016 Hon’ble Mr. J. Valmiki Mehta of Delhi High Court ruled-
If a person dies after passing of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 and there is no HUF existing at the time of the death of such a person, inheritance of an immovable property of such a person by his successors-in-interest is no doubt inheritance of an ‘ancestral’ property but the inheritance is as a self acquired property in the hands of the successor and not as an HUF property although the successor(s) indeed inherits ‘ancestral’ property i.e. a property belonging to his paternal ancestor.

I could have explained more if background is known to me. I am at your service if you visit my office. 
Please click on LIKE BUTTON.
										
									 
									
									Dear client, 

When grandfather dies without making a will, the property goes to the father and then to the grandchild from the father. A property is known as ancestral property when it has passed undivided for four generations. As the property here is grandfather’s property and not great grandfather’s property, it is not ancestral property and therefore son will not have any rights in that property against his father. If the father dies without making a will, all the legal hires will have equal rights in the property as per Indian succession act.

									Dear Client, 
1. Yes, you can file execution petition even though appeal has been filed.
2. Order 41 Rule 5 (1) CPC provides:

Rule 5. Stay by Appellate Court.— (1) An appeal shall not operate as a stay of proceedings under a decree or order appealed from except so far as the Appellate Court may order, nor shall execution of a decree be stayed by reason only of an appeal having been preferred from the decree; but the Appellate Court may for sufficient cause order stay of execution of such decree. So, the filing of appeal does not automatically operate as a stay of decree or order appealed from, unless Appellate court passes an order of stay.
3. “Section 125(3) of the code would have to be held to be confined to the section which precedes it.” Section 128 of the Code provides for enforcement of the order of maintenance against the person against whom the order of maintenance has been made. The enforcement of the order of maintenance under Section 128 can only be made upon the liability being satisfied by making actual payment of the amount of maintenance, which is due. The entitlement to claim enforcement of the order of maintenance under Section 128 by seeking discharge of the liability as per terms of the order of maintenance granted under Section 125, therefore cannot be held to be extinguished in terms of the one year limitation prescribed under the first proviso to Section 125(3).
Thank you

This means that the marriage of a girl below the age of 18 is considered to be child marriage and is prohibited by the law. There are certain contradictions to this rule in personal laws. However, it is important for you, as parents, to understand the importance of encouraging your daughters to continue their education and empowering them in other ways rather than marrying them off at a young age.
•	The Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 1971 lays down the law regarding abortion in India. Right now, it is not easy to get an abortion even in cases of rape as this Act sets a number of conditions. However, this Act is soon to be amended.
•	Domestic violence is prohibited by law and is considered to be a criminal offence according to S. 498-A of the Indian Penal Code. Certain provisions in the Indian Evidence Act and the Criminal Procedure Codealso deal with this issue. Finally, a legislation devoted to this issue was enacted in 2005 – The Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act.
•	Another common problem faced by married women is harassment from their in-laws for dowry. To battle this social evil, the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961 was enacted, criminalising this practice. However, it still continues. It is important that parents do not give in to societal pressures and ensure that they do not provide dowry in any form.
•	While Indian law does not criminalise pre-marital sex as long as it is between consenting adults, there are no laws regulating live-in relationships. However, courts have developed laws on this subject through decisions in cases to such an extent that the law against domestic violence applies to couples who are in live-in relationships and children born out of such relationships are treated as legitimate in certain circumstances.
Sexual Abuse and Exploitation:
•	Various forms of sexual harassment such as singing lewd songs, eve-teasing, making sexual advances in spite of refusal, watching, capturing or sharing images and other media of a woman engaging in a private act without prior consent have all been criminalised by the Indian Penal Code. There is an entire legislation dedicated to sexual harassment in the workplace – Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013.
•	As parents, it is important that you are aware of your daughters’ activities on the Internet. Today, many crimes against women are committed by sexual predators through online portals. Online harassment of women is prohibited under S. 67 of the Information Technology Act.
•	Any indecent representation of women is banned by the Indecent Representation of Women (Prohibition) Act, 1986. This law, as it is considered to be too narrow for this day and age, has undergone certain changes and an Amendment Bill was drafted in 2012 which broadened its scope.
•	Ss. 375 and 376(2) of The Indian Penal Code criminalise rape. These sections spell out 7 years’ and 10 years’ imprisonment, respectively, as the punishment for rape. The key feature of these sections is the requirement for consent by the woman in question for the act not to be considered as rape. Thus, as a parent it is important that you explain the concept of consent to your daughters at an early age. Intercourse with a woman of unsound mind or a girl below 16 years of age is considered to be rape irrespective of consent being given. Unfortunately, marital rape has not yet been criminalised.
Property Laws:
•	While traditionally, the rights of women with regard to succession and inheritance of property in India were next to non-existent, as of now, according to the amendments to the Hindu Succession Act in 2005, daughters have been given the same rights as sons with regard to inheritance and succession.
•	The Indian Succession Act does not differentiate between the heirs of the deceased.
•	Muslim women enjoy rights of inheritance though limited to some extent by custom and practice.
Women in the Workplace:
•	Women in India have the right to earn as much as men and gender discrimination is also prohibited at the time of recruitment. Ss. 4 and 5 of the Equal Remunerations Act, 1976 lay down the law regarding this.
•	The Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017 has brought about certain groundbreaking laws which concern working women including the increase of paid maternity leave from 12 weeks to 26 weeks (S.5(3)) and ‘work from home’ options for new mothers (S.5(5)).
Organisations that help:
There are a number of organisations that work for the upliftment and protection of women such as the National Commission for Women, One Stop Crisis Centres (or) Nirbhaya Centres, National Association of Rural Women India, etc. There are also a number of NGOs working for women’s rights. Please keep your daughter informed of these organisations so that she knows who to approach in case of a crisis.
While keeping your daughter informed of her rights is a basic obligation of every parent, it is also important that you take a more active part in ensuring that your daughter has a better and happier future. By taking steps such as not providing dowry and by shifting the focus from marriage to education, you can do your part in breaking a cycle of abuse that has been going on for centuries. However, to ensure a complete change in society’s views on women, it is essential that you teach not only your daughters but also your sons to recognise the problems faced by women today and how to treat women with the respect that is their due.

									In the context of a restitution of conjugal rights (RCR) case, an "Await Commissioner Warrant/Report" typically refers to a stage in the legal proceedings. It involves the court appointing a commissioner to investigate and report on the specific circumstances and living conditions of the parties involved in the RCR case.

The purpose of this investigation is to determine whether the party seeking restitution of conjugal rights (usually one of the spouses) is justified in seeking the court's intervention to restore conjugal rights, which generally means requesting that the other spouse returns to the matrimonial home and resumes cohabitation. The commissioner may visit the homes of the parties involved, interview them, and gather relevant information.

The commissioner's report can provide valuable insights to the court when deciding on the RCR case. If the commissioner's report suggests that the conditions are favorable for reconciliation and resumption of cohabitation, it may influence the court's decision in favor of the party seeking restitution of conjugal rights.

									Under the Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act (HAMA), the adoption of a son is a legal process that must adhere to certain formalities. While the Act doesn't explicitly mandate a specific "giving and taking" ceremony, it does require adherence to certain essential formalities for a valid adoption deed. These formalities include:

Consent of Parties: The biological parents (if alive) or the legal guardians must willingly give the child in adoption, and the adopting parents must willingly accept the child for the adoption to be valid.

Transfer of Rights: There should be a transfer of parental rights from the biological parents or guardians to the adoptive parents. This is generally expressed in a deed of adoption.

Registration: HAMA requires the adoption deed to be registered. The deed should also be signed by the parties involved and attested by at least two witnesses.

No Specific Ceremony: While there is no strict requirement for a specific "giving and taking" ceremony, some families may choose to have a formal or customary ceremony to mark the adoption. However, the absence of such a ceremony does not necessarily invalidate the adoption if the other legal requirements are met.

									In India, the possession and carrying of weapons, including knives, in public places are regulated by the Arms Act, 1959, and its corresponding rules. Carrying a kitchen knife or any other sharp object for self-defense in public places can be subject to legal restrictions. Here are some important points to consider:

Arms Act, 1959: The Arms Act, 1959, regulates the possession and carrying of arms and ammunition in India. It divides firearms into two categories: Prohibited Bore (PB) and Non-Prohibited Bore (NPB). While a kitchen knife is not a firearm, it can still be subject to scrutiny under the Act, particularly if it's being carried for self-defense.

Rules and Licenses: The Arms Rules, 1962, provide further details and regulations regarding the possession, acquisition, and carrying of arms. To carry a weapon legally in public places, you would typically need a valid license issued by the local licensing authority.

Intent and Use: It's essential to understand that carrying a kitchen knife or any other object with the intent of using it as a weapon for self-defense might not be viewed favorably under the law. The law generally does not encourage individuals to take the law into their own hands.

Alternatives: Instead of carrying potentially dangerous items for self-defense, you should consider non-lethal alternatives. Personal safety items like pepper spray, personal alarms, or self-defense courses are options that are typically less restricted by the law and can provide you with a degree of protection.

Local Regulations: Laws can vary by state and locality in India, so it's important to check with local law enforcement or legal authorities to understand specific regulations that may apply in your area.

headline: Noisy Neigbours, sleep disturbance
data:

Their household activity starts around 6am and goes till 9am. During this time there is noise of chairs etc. dragging, putting of heavy object on the floor etc. These noises are not continuous but on intermittent interval gap of 20-25 mins. However they are loud enough to wake someone from sleep.
      I tried talking to the tenant but he is arrogant. Even talking to the owner didn't help. I am not expecting any output from society association because as per them the silent hours is from 10pm to 6am. 'But does that mean disturbance can be done post 6am??'
      My senior citizen father doesn't experience the sound much as he is in other room and also he wakes up early. I haven't got complete sleep since last month, it has affected my job productivity, feel very lethargic, sleepy, irritated throughout the day, overall my health affected.
      Kindly guide how to deal with this. I don't want to go for police complain but can I inform to him for the complaint (or any other approach) so that it might create fear in his mind and cooperate. I want them to gently do the activities that time so that the noise will be reduced. I don't want to make the matter complicated. Please help.

									 Change your residence . sorry no legal remedy

The sound they are making are reasonable sounds and not extraordinary sounds like loud music, shouting, fighting etc. There are also doing it from 6 am, so nothing is wrong in it. 
Plus, even your father who is a senior citizen has no problem with it. So, no case can be made out. You should talk to them softly and try to convince them.
Thank you										
									 
									
									How to File a Harassment Complaint Against a Neighbour
Is Calling Police an Option?
Yes, calling a police if your neighbor harasses you is an option to go with. You have the option to call the police by just dialing the police number 100 and police will come to the place mentioned by you in the phone call. They will come to the spot and ask you the problem and then will take the action against them. And, when they will reach the spot you should be having sufficient proof to prove the harassment by neighbors.
Harassment Through Nuisance
You may be living in an apartment or in a duplex, often it happens, when you hear loud music sound from the neighbor’s house, you try to ignore that sound for as long as possible but sometimes, such noise may make life difficult. This type of nuisance is defined in Section 268 of the Indian Penal Act.
Section 268 of the Indian Penal Code defines nuisance when the person is guilty of a public nuisance when he does any act which causes injury, danger or annoyance to the public or the people in general who live or occupy the property in the neighborhood.
A common nuisance is not excused on the ground that it causes some convenience or advantage.
If this type of harassment is faced by you from your neighbor then, you can file an application under Section 268 of IPC in the court of magistrate.
Punishment of nuisance is defined in Section 290 of IPC, which is mere Rs. 200 but the court can do much more.
As a matter of fact, calling 100 is most effective as, after a visit or two from the police, such nuisance is likely to stop. In extreme cases, police may even confiscate the instruments that are used to cause nuisance like – loudspeakers or sound boxes, or drones, cameras or such other tools.
Sometimes, police does not intervene despite laws being there as they do not like extra work on their plate or because the other party is very influential. In such cases, you may need to take help of legal experts. We recommend you get in touch with ClikLawyer.com.
Harassment Through Mischief
When you live in a duplex, you are sharing a common wall. If your neighbor starts construction in that common wall you do not have the right to stop him from constructing because it is his legal right but if during the construction work your property gets damaged, you can ask him to compensate for the loss suffered by you but if your neighbor refuses to pay you the amount then you can file a case under –
Section 425 of IPC which states that whoever with intent to cause, or knowing that he is likely to cause, wrongful loss or damage to the public or to any person, causes the destruction of any property, or any such change in any property or in the situation thereof as destroys or diminishes its value or utility, or affects it injuriously, commits mischief.
You can file suit for declaration and mandatory injunction in a civil court as well.
You can claim damages in the same suit.

headline: Gift Deed Vs Relinquishment Deed
data:
I have inherited some property, both movable & immovable, along with my sister. Both holding the undivided equal share of those.

I don’t wish to claim the right to my share, and instead, wish to give away my share of all these inherited assets, both movable & immovable, to my sister.

Requesting your opinion and advice on what would be the best way for that?

To execute a Gift deed or a Relinquishment Deed ?
What are the specific differences between the two ?
And what the clear cut advantage & disadvantage of one above the other ? 
which of the two options is better advised?

Thanks and regards, 									
									 
									
									No difference in either method it is conveyance and see if there is difference in stamp duty then follow cheaper   Relinquishments equivalent to sale without consideration so is gift . no difference 										
									 
									
									

1.	Stamp duty on gift deed is 0.5 to 0.7 per cent of depending on property value in WB—stamp duty on relinquishment deed is 4 to 6 per cent. 
2.	In gift deed the doner transfers the property to person of his/her choice—in relinquishment deed the executer renounces his right in the property, that is, the property will go the person or persons who is or are entitled to the property.
3.	A gift deed is transfer property to a particular person, there are two parties involved—in languishment deed there is only a declaration  by executer stating I hereby relinquish my right in the property. There is only person involved in relinquishment deed. 
4.	It is safer to execute gift deed. Future legal complications to the donee are lesser in gift deed. 
5.	For further clarification and draft of gift deed contact me through Pathlegal. Hit the like button if answer is useful to you.  
										
									 
									
									Dear Client, 
A Gift deed is transfer of property rights to another person without any consideration. A relinquishment deed is a deed that mentions that you will give up your rights on the property to a certain person. Stamp duties are lesser when making a gift deed than when compared to relinquishment deed. Plus, Gifts to blood relatives, as inheritance, as marriage gifts, or in contemplation of death, are generally not taxable. There are no tax benefits for a 'transfer' under Relinquishment Deed.
 Moreover, it is just as challengable as a release deed. So, it functions just like release deed. There are no tax benefits for a 'transfer' under Relinquishment Deed. 
Thank you

Regarding Section 6 of the Civil Procedure Code (CPC), it provides for exclusion of time in certain cases. This provision is independent of the Limitation Act, 1963.

While it is generally good practice to mention the relevant provisions in the plaint for clarity, the failure to expressly plead these sections may not necessarily preclude the court from considering them if their application is apparent from the facts presented.

Courts are often guided by the principles of substantial justice, and they may take cognizance of provisions related to limitation even if not expressly mentioned in the plaint. However, it is always safer and more effective to make explicit references to the relevant sections in the plaint to avoid any ambiguity.

7. Section 477A - Falsification of accounts: If the forgery involves falsifying accounts, this section may be applicable.

You need to make a single pronouncement of Talaq during Tuhr (period of purity). After single pronouncement wife has to observe three iddat, subsequent  to which  Talaq becomes final. 
1.	Visit Kazi of your local Masjid with two male adult Muslim witnesses.

									Dear Client, 
You may consider these forms of divorce:
Khula:
Khula means literally to take off clothes and hence to lay ones authority over a wife. Under Muslim Law, a marriage can be terminated either at the will of husband or wife or by a mutual agreement by the two. If the marriage is dissolved at the request of husband then it is known as Talaq.
Similarly, the wife can also divorce her husband if she is satisfied that the two of them are not able to perform their matrimonial ties. The Muslim woman can release herself from the marital tie by giving up some property in consideration for which the husband is to give her a Khula and when they have done this a Talaq-ul-bain would take place.
Talaq-E-Tafweez:
It is also known as Delegated Divorce. The delegation of power to dissolve is technically called tafweez. Tafweez means to make someone the owner of an act which appertains to the person making the tafweez. Talaq-e-tafweez is one of the most important forms of divorce under Muslim Law because it gives to Muslim women a right to divorce their husband without going to court of law. In this form of divorce a Muslim male can delegate his power of repudiation of marriage to a third person or to his wife also. He can delegate his own right of pronouncing divorce to his wife. 									Even though Talaq-e-Bid'ah (Triple Talaq) is declared unconstitutional and invalid by the Supreme Court, but other forms of Triple Talk can be utilised. :
1. Talaq-e-Hasan (Ahsan): This is the preferred and lawful form of divorce in Islam. In this type, the husband pronounces Talaq once, and a waiting period (iddah) begins during which the wife observes a period of abstinence. The husband can revoke the divorce during this time, and if they have sexual relations during this period, the divorce is automatically revoked. If the iddah period expires without reconciliation, the divorce is finalized.
Talaq-e-Hasan (Hasan): In this form, the husband pronounces Talaq twice, with a waiting period (iddah) after each pronouncement. If he does not revoke the divorce during the iddah, the third pronouncement would make the divorce final. The idea here is to provide a cooling-off period for possible reconciliation.

Khula: In Shia law, a wife can also initiate a divorce by seeking a Khula. This is a process where the wife offers compensation to the husband in exchange for her release from the marriage.

Regarding the question of sanction for the prosecution of government employees, that requirement is generally covered under CrPC Section 197. This provision is in place to protect government employees from frivolous or malicious prosecutions that may hinder the discharge of their official duties.

headline: Being a de facto complainant can a person be denied copy of judgement
data:
How Is it possible that someone being defacto complainant and victim also, he is not be able to get a certified copy of a highcourt bail order ??Can a judge specifically set some conditions like that??									
									 
									
									Dear brother / sister
you can get the copy of the bail order through the  public prosecutor or the police
Advocate, A.P.Loganathan, Madras High Court
Please click LIKE for encouraging/appreciating me
For more clarification contact me, getting details from path legal or Google site
										
									 
									
									Dear Client, 
It is not the judge who sets out conditions like that. It is that they follow the decisions in the previously decided cases. De facto complainant is like a third party to the complaint, once the prosecutor is appointed. Then, he has no right to oppose any bail, request re-investigation or so on. 
Every party before the court needs to have a locus standi, but when the case is under the Public Prosecutor, the complainant becomes defacto complainant whose role is to "assist" and not "lead" the proceedings. 
For there is no locus standi to defacto complainant, he has no right per se to see any bail order as such.
Thank you

Can A Foreign Citizen Inherit A Property In India? What’s The Inheritance Procedure Concerning NRI’s Property In India?
Guiding Businesses

Can A Foreign Citizen Inherit A Property In India? What’s The Inheritance Procedure Concerning NRI’s Property In India?

Who can inherit property
Indian citizens can inherit properties in India without any restrictions. However, when we talk about foreign citizens and Indian citizens living abroad, the situation is not the same. To understand the law regarding inheritance of such persons, we need to understand the following terms:

Foreigner: The term foreigner has been defined in the Foreigners Act, 1946 as ‘a person who is not a citizen of India’.
NRI: In simple terms, Non-Resident Indian (“NRI”) can be defined, as an Indian citizen who has relocated to another country, which is no longer ‘resident’ in India. More clarity regarding this can be found in the Income-tax Act, 1961, which does not directly define NRI but defines who can be considered as a resident in Section 6. Therefore, interpreting the section, the following criteria can be laid down for someone to be considered as NRI:
A person who has stayed less than 182 days in the current financial year in India; or
A person who has stayed in India for less 365 days in the preceding four years and has stayed less than 60 days in that current financial year.
If a person fulfils even one of the above-mentioned conditions, he shall be regarded as a ‘non-resident.’

FEMA defines a person resident in India as

a person residing in India for more than one hundred and eighty-two days during the preceding financial year but does not include:

 (A) a person who has gone out of India or who stays outside India, in either case—
(a) for or on taking up employment outside India, or

(b) for carrying on outside India a business or vocation outside India, or

c) for any other purpose, in such circumstances as would indicate his intention to stay outside India for an uncertain period;

(B) a person who has come to or stays in India, in either case, otherwise than—

(a) for or on taking up employment in India, or

(b) for carrying on in India a business or vocation in India, or

(c) for any other purpose, in such circumstances as would indicate his intention to stay in India for an uncertain period;

(2) any person or body corporate registered or incorporated in India,

(3) an office, branch or agency in India owned or controlled by a person resident outside India,

(4) an office, branch or agency outside India owned or controlled by a person resident in India;

Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999 uses the term “person resident outside India”  for NRIs and defines it as a person who is not resident in India.

PIO: The Ministry of External Affairs defines Person of Indian Origin (PIO) as a foreign citizen (except a national of Pakistan, Afghanistan Bangladesh, China, Iran, Bhutan, Sri Lanka, and Nepal):
Who at any time held an Indian passport; or
Either of their parents/ grandparents/ great grandparents were born and permanently resident in India as defined in Government of India Act, 1935 and other territories that became part of India thereafter provided neither was at any time a citizen of any of the aforesaid countries ( as referred above); or
Who is a spouse of a citizen of India or a PIO
The economic, financial, and educational benefits given to them are usually at parity with NRIs.

Who can they inherit from
NRIs, PIO, and even foreign citizens can inherit any type of property, including movable and immovable property, i.e. commercial, agricultural, and residential. It is pertinent to note that NRI cannot acquire agricultural land, farmhouse, and plantation property in India, but they can inherit the same subject to certain restrictions. They can also inherit properties from other NRIs and PIOs if certain conditions are fulfilled. Therefore, they can inherit property from two categories of people:

Any person resident in India; or

A person resident outside India
One of the things required to enable NRIs to inherit the property is that the property, at the time of the purchase, should be in compliance with the relevant laws. That is the person bequeathing the property should have complied with the Foreign Exchange Management Act (“FEMA”) Regulations or any other foreign exchange law in force at the time of acquisition of the property in question. Non-compliance with the same can result in non-inheritance of the property.

In what ways can they inherit the property?
As a general rule, people, including NRIs, can inherit a property in the following ways:

Will: One of the ways that NRIs can inherit properties in India is through a Will. NRIs themselves can transfer the property to other NRIs by making through a Will. However, in the said circumstance, the permission of RBI will be required.
Intestate: If a person dies intestate, i.e. without a Will, then the inheritance process can get a little difficult. The relevant provision of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 and shall apply. An NRI would have to apply for a succession certificate to the Courts. For this several documents including the death certificate of the relative, birth certificate, purchase deed, registration documents, bank documents, etc. have to be produced to prove that you are the rightful heir to the property.
Gift: An Indian resident can gift a property to an NRI residing outside India. The same shall not be taxable. However, there is one restriction. Agricultural land and farmhouse cannot be gifted to a person residing outside India. Therefore, NRIs cannot receive agricultural land as a gift.

headline: HARSH VARDHAN SOLANKI VERSUS CBSE AND ZENITH PUBLIC SCHOOL KHURJA
data:
IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT ALLAHABAD

HARSH VARDHAN SOLANKI (Petitioner)

VERSUS

CBSE BOARD AND ZENITH PUBLIC SCHOOL, KHURJA (Respondents)

"PETITION"

Grounds:

1. The Petitioner is a student who passed his 10th class in 2022 from Zenith Public School, Khurja.

2. There is a typographical error in the Petitioner's date of birth in his 10th class marksheet. The correct date of birth is 16th May 2005, but it is mentioned as 16th May 2007 in the marksheet.

3. The Petitioner has been trying to get the error corrected for the past 2-3 months, but the school and the CBSE board have not taken any action.

4. The Petitioner's college admission is dependent on the correction of the error in his date of birth.

5. The Petitioner's right to education is being violated due to the inaction of the school and the CBSE board.

Prayers:

1. Issue a writ of mandamus directing the Respondents to correct the error in the Petitioner's date of birth in his 10th class marksheet within a period of 4 weeks.

2. Award costs to the Petitioner.

3. Pass any other order or direction as the Court may deem fit.

Legal Sections and Articles:

1. Article 21 of the Constitution of India: Right to life and personal liberty

2. Article 39(a) of the Constitution of India: Equal opportunity to all citizens

3. Article 45 of the Constitution of India: Free and compulsory education for all children until the age of 14

4. Section 26 of the Right to Education Act, 2009: No child shall be subjected to any physical punishment or mental harassment

5. Section 11 of the CBSE Bye-laws, 2018: The Board shall provide for the issue of marksheets to candidates who have passed the Board's examinations.

For Statement for Every Section and Article:

1. Article 21 of the Constitution of India: The right to education is a fundamental right under Article 21 of the Constitution of India. The Petitioner's right to education is being violated due to the inaction of the Respondents.

2. Article 39(a) of the Constitution of India: Article 39(a) of the Constitution of India guarantees equal opportunity to all citizens. The Petitioner is being denied equal opportunity due to the inaction of the Respondents.

3. Article 45 of the Constitution of India: Article 45 of the Constitution of India provides for free and compulsory education for all children until the age of 14. The Petitioner is being denied his right to free and compulsory education due to the inaction of the Respondents.

4. Section 26 of the Right to Education Act, 2009: Section 26 of the Right to Education Act, 2009 prohibits any physical punishment or mental harassment of children. The Petitioner is being subjected to mental harassment due to the inaction of the Respondents.

5. Section 11 of the CBSE Bye-laws, 2018: Section 11 of the CBSE Bye-laws, 2018 obliges the CBSE Board to issue marksheets to candidates who have passed the Board's examinations. The Respondents are in violation of this provision by not correcting the error in the Petitioner's marksheet.

Prayers for Strict Law Charges to the Guilty and Articles and Sections for Petitioner's Time Waste, Articles and Sections for Not Updating Petitioner's Date of Birth, Articles and Sections for Not Giving Petitioner the Correct Answers, Articles and Sections for Not Serving India and Ignoring the Problem, Articles and Sections for Directions to Lower Courts to Ensure Law is Properly Followed :

1. Section 166 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860: Public servant disobeying law, with intent to cause injury to any person


2. Section 293 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860: Negligent act causing death

3. Section 409 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860: Criminal breach of trust by public servant, or by banker, merchant or agent

4. Section 417 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860: Cheating by personation

5. Section 420 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property

6. Section 423 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860: Fraudulent execution of deed of transfer containing false statement

There are certain limitations as to the grounds of challenge  of arbitration award:

									If a case has been registered against you under Section 420 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC), which pertains to cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property, and you wish to apply for anticipatory bail, here are the steps you should consider:

Consult with an Attorney: It is crucial to seek legal advice from a criminal defense attorney as soon as possible. They will be able to provide you with guidance specific to your case, assess the situation, and help you prepare for the bail application.

Gather Relevant Documents: Collect all relevant documents, including the FIR, complaint, and any evidence that can help support your case. Your attorney will need this information to prepare your bail application.

Prepare Your Anticipatory Bail Application: Your attorney will help you draft an anticipatory bail application. In this application, you should include details about the case, reasons why you believe you are entitled to anticipatory bail, and any supporting evidence or arguments.

File the Application: Your attorney will help you file the anticipatory bail application with the appropriate court, which may be the Sessions Court or the High Court, depending on the severity of the case. It's essential to file the application as soon as possible to prevent your arrest.

Notice to the Prosecutor: Once the application is filed, the court will issue a notice to the public prosecutor to respond to your bail plea.

Hearing: A date for the bail hearing will be scheduled. Your attorney will represent you in court during the hearing.

Arguments: During the hearing, your attorney will present arguments in support of your anticipatory bail application. These may include reasons why you should be granted bail, such as no likelihood of absconding, cooperating with the investigation, and being willing to appear before the authorities as required.

Conditions: The court may grant you anticipatory bail with certain conditions, such as requiring you to cooperate with the investigation, not leaving the jurisdiction, or providing a personal bond or surety.

Follow Court Orders: If the court grants anticipatory bail, it's essential to adhere to the conditions set by the court. Failure to do so can lead to the cancellation of your bail.

Monitoring the Case: Continue to work closely with your attorney to monitor the progress of your case and to ensure you comply with all legal requirements.

Anticipatory bail is not an absolute right, and whether or not it's granted depends on the facts and circumstances of your case.  Section 8 of Hindu Succession  Act: 
====================================================================
General rules of succession in the case of males.―The property of a male Hindu dying intestate
shall devolve according to the provisions of this Chapter:―
(a) firstly, upon the heirs, being the relatives specified in class I of the Schedule;

CLASS I

Son; daughter; widow; mother; son of a pre-deceased son; daughter of a pre-deceased son; son of a pre-deceased daughter; daughter of a pre-deceased daughter; widow of a pre-deceased son; son of a pre-deceased son of a pre-deceased son; daughter of a pre-deceased son of a pre-deceased son; widow of a pre-deceased son of a pre-deceased son.

=============================================================================
Distribution of Property after Death – Hindu Male
For Hindus, testamentary succession (succession by way of Will) is as per the Indian Succession Act and intestate succession (succession without Will) is as per the Hindu Succession Act. In this article, we look in detail the process for distribution of property after death of a Hindu male as per the Hindu Succession Act.
Class 1 Heirs
The Hindu Succession Act groups the heirs of a male Hindu into four categories and lays down that his/her inheritable property devolves firstly upon the heirs specified in Class I which are as under:
•	Sons
•	Daughters
•	Widow
•	Mother
•	Son of a pre-deceased son
•	Daughter of a pre-deceased son
•	Son of a pre-deceased daughter
•	Daughter of a pre-deceased daughter
•	Widow of a pre-deceased son
•	Son of a pre-deceased son of a pre-deceased son
•	Daughter of a pre-deceased son of a pre-deceased son
•	Widow of a pre-deceased son of a pre-deceased son
•	Son of a predeceased daughter of a predeceased daughter
•	Daughter of a deceased daughter of a predeceased daughter
•	Daughter of a predeceased son of a predeceased daughter
•	Daughter of a predeceased daughter of predeceased son
All these heirs inherit simultaneously and to the exclusion of other heirs. In the absence of any of the heirs in this category, the property devolves upon the enumerated heirs specified in class II.
Class 2 Heirs
The devolution in Class II heirs is made in the absence of any heir in Class I and in such a manner that heirs specified in a particular entry share equally. For this purpose if more than one heir is specified in a single entry, they share the property simultaneously and equally to the exclusion of those specified in subsequent entries. Class 2 heirs include:
•	Father
•	Sons daughter’s son
•	Sons daughter’s daughter
•	Brother
•	Sister
•	Daughters son’s son
•	Daughters son’s daughter
•	Daughters daughter’s son
•	Daughters Daughter’s daughter
•	Brothers son
•	Sisters son
•	Brothers daughter
•	Sisters daughter
•	Fathers father
•	Fathers mother
•	Fathers widow
•	Brothers widow
•	Fathers brother
•	Fathers sister
•	Mothers father
•	Mothers mother
•	Mothers brother
•	Mothers sister
Agnates
In case a Hindu male passes away intestate and leaves no class 1 or class 2 heirs, then the property would devolve on agnates. A person is said to be an agnate of another if the two are related by blood or adoption wholly through males. Agnate relationship does not extend to relationship by marriage and is restricted to relationship by blood. Also, agnate does not include widows of lineal descendants of the intestate.
Cognates
If a Hindu male passes away without a Will and has no class 1 or class 2 heirs or agnates, then the succession would be through cognates. Cognates are ones who are related to the intestate by blood or adoption but not wholly, through males. Thus mother’s brother’s son and brother’s daughters son are cognates, eligible for heirship.

headline: Miamtenance for live in partner under sec 125 crpc
data:

It is true that sec. 125 on a plain reading applies to "wife, however, as per many judgments of Supreme Court the word "wife" has been made to include even women in live-in relationships.
The Conditions that must be proved by woman in live-in relationship: 
(a) The couple must hold themselves out to society as being akin to spouses.
(b) They must be of legal age to marry.
(c) They must be otherwise qualified to enter into a legal marriage, including being unmarried.
(d) They must have voluntarily cohabited and held themselves out to the world as being akin to spouses for a significant period of time.
It has also been highlighted that the live-in relationship must be "relationship like marriage." So, if you have evidence to show that you lived together casually not as husband and wife. If you have introduced yourselves to others as a married couple etc.

									It seems like you are dealing with a complex issue involving your neighbor's behavior and the use of common spaces in your chawl. To address the concerns you've raised, you may consider taking the following steps:

Municipal Complaints: If your neighbor is engaging in activities that are causing public nuisance or violating municipal bylaws, you can file complaints with your local municipal corporation (Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation or BMC in the case of Mumbai). This can include issues like blocking common areas, illegal constructions, and improper disposal of waste. Provide as much evidence as possible, such as photographs and records of incidents.

Legal Action: If your neighbor's actions continue to be disruptive, and you believe they are encroaching on common spaces, you may want to consult with a local lawyer to understand your options for taking legal action. Legal proceedings can be initiated, but the duration of the case can vary significantly depending on the complexity of the matter, the local court's backlog, and other factors.

Mediation: Sometimes, it's beneficial to seek mediation or reconciliation with your neighbor to try and resolve the issues amicably. Mediation can be faster and less adversarial than legal action.

Police Complaints: If there are physical altercations or threats of violence, you should report these incidents to the local police. The police will investigate and, if warranted, take appropriate action.

Documentation: Keep thorough records of all incidents, complaints, and interactions with your neighbor. This documentation can be valuable if you need to present evidence in a legal case.

Consult a Local Attorney: Consult with a local attorney who specializes in property and housing matters. They can provide guidance specific to your local laws and regulations, helping you understand your rights and options.

Regarding the duration of a legal case, it can vary widely depending on the complexity of the case, the number of parties involved, the evidence presented, and the court's caseload. Legal proceedings in India can sometimes take several years to conclude, but it's essential to consult with a legal professional who can give you a more accurate estimate based on your specific circumstances.

In the meantime, you should continue to report any illegal activities, nuisances, or encroachments to the relevant authorities and maintain proper documentation of these incidents to support any future legal actions.

headline: Alienation after informing the buyer about the pending suit
data:
There is a plot of 500 sq.yds. where I own 60 % undivided share and the other 40 % undivided share is held by another person named "X". The respective shares of 60% and 40% are not in dispute and even the Plaintiff "X" acknowledges the same in his Plaint. It's only a Partition Suit.
"X" erected an unauthorised construction for which the civic authorities issued notices for demolition.
"X" being an advocate submitted two IA's for injunction, one against the demolition and the other against the alienation of my share of the property and they are still under the consideration of the court and no injunction order is passed.

Meanwhile if I alienate my share of property of 60 %, after informing the new buyer about the pending case as the respective shares are not in dispute. What should I submit to the court to relieve myself from the suit and how the new buyer will proceed with the suit.									
									 
									
									Say u informed the buyer he will replace in place of you tell through advocate inform other party also										
									 
									
									Dear Client, 
If a person knowingly buys a property in dispute, then he will replace you in the dispute. He will be bound by the decision of the Court.  It means that suppose, the Court says to compromise or to pay some amount of money, then the buyer will have to pay from his own pocket, even though he was not a party to the dispute.  
Answering your question regarding relieving yourself from the suit, you can consider withdrawing the case or compromising with the other party. If you want to still sell your property, you will have to inform the other party regarding the sale agreement through notice and the Court as well. 
Thank you

headline: Alienation of property before injunction order
data:
There is a plot of 500 sq.yds. where I own 60 % share and the other 40 % is held by another person named "X". The latter erected an unauthorised construction for which the civic authorities issued notices for demolition.
"X" being an advocate submitted two IA's for injunction, one against the demolition and the other against the alienation of my share of the property and they are still under the consideration of the court and no injunction order is passed. 
 
Meanwhile if I alienate my share of property of 60 %, what should I submit to the court to relieve myself from the suit and how the new buyer will proceed with the suit.									
									 
									
									Dear Client, 
As per Sec. 52 of Transfer of Property Act,  any immovable property under a title dispute cannot be transferred or disposed of until the litigation is pending or until the court of competent jurisdiction makes a judgement in the matter. The transfer made by you will make the new buyer stand in your place. Then the new buyer will have to do what should have been done by you to execute the Court order. 
It is preferable to not transfer your property during pendency of a suit because, if the new buyer finds out that you sold it him knowingly then a cheating case mayalso be filed against you. 
Thank you
