									 Section 8 of Hindu Succession  Act: 
====================================================================
General rules of succession in the case of males.―The property of a male Hindu dying intestate
shall devolve according to the provisions of this Chapter:―
(a) firstly, upon the heirs, being the relatives specified in class I of the Schedule;

CLASS I

Son; daughter; widow; mother; son of a pre-deceased son; daughter of a pre-deceased son; son of a pre-deceased daughter; daughter of a pre-deceased daughter; widow of a pre-deceased son; son of a pre-deceased son of a pre-deceased son; daughter of a pre-deceased son of a pre-deceased son; widow of a pre-deceased son of a pre-deceased son.

=============================================================================
Distribution of Property after Death – Hindu Male
For Hindus, testamentary succession (succession by way of Will) is as per the Indian Succession Act and intestate succession (succession without Will) is as per the Hindu Succession Act. In this article, we look in detail the process for distribution of property after death of a Hindu male as per the Hindu Succession Act.
Class 1 Heirs
The Hindu Succession Act groups the heirs of a male Hindu into four categories and lays down that his/her inheritable property devolves firstly upon the heirs specified in Class I which are as under:
•	Sons
•	Daughters
•	Widow
•	Mother
•	Son of a pre-deceased son
•	Daughter of a pre-deceased son
•	Son of a pre-deceased daughter
•	Daughter of a pre-deceased daughter
•	Widow of a pre-deceased son
•	Son of a pre-deceased son of a pre-deceased son
•	Daughter of a pre-deceased son of a pre-deceased son
•	Widow of a pre-deceased son of a pre-deceased son
•	Son of a predeceased daughter of a predeceased daughter
•	Daughter of a deceased daughter of a predeceased daughter
•	Daughter of a predeceased son of a predeceased daughter
•	Daughter of a predeceased daughter of predeceased son
All these heirs inherit simultaneously and to the exclusion of other heirs. In the absence of any of the heirs in this category, the property devolves upon the enumerated heirs specified in class II.
Class 2 Heirs
The devolution in Class II heirs is made in the absence of any heir in Class I and in such a manner that heirs specified in a particular entry share equally. For this purpose if more than one heir is specified in a single entry, they share the property simultaneously and equally to the exclusion of those specified in subsequent entries. Class 2 heirs include:
•	Father
•	Sons daughter’s son
•	Sons daughter’s daughter
•	Brother
•	Sister
•	Daughters son’s son
•	Daughters son’s daughter
•	Daughters daughter’s son
•	Daughters Daughter’s daughter
•	Brothers son
•	Sisters son
•	Brothers daughter
•	Sisters daughter
•	Fathers father
•	Fathers mother
•	Fathers widow
•	Brothers widow
•	Fathers brother
•	Fathers sister
•	Mothers father
•	Mothers mother
•	Mothers brother
•	Mothers sister
Agnates
In case a Hindu male passes away intestate and leaves no class 1 or class 2 heirs, then the property would devolve on agnates. A person is said to be an agnate of another if the two are related by blood or adoption wholly through males. Agnate relationship does not extend to relationship by marriage and is restricted to relationship by blood. Also, agnate does not include widows of lineal descendants of the intestate.
Cognates
If a Hindu male passes away without a Will and has no class 1 or class 2 heirs or agnates, then the succession would be through cognates. Cognates are ones who are related to the intestate by blood or adoption but not wholly, through males. Thus mother’s brother’s son and brother’s daughters son are cognates, eligible for heirship.

									In India, including Bangalore, changing or removing a surname from academic documents typically involves a legal process, and it cannot be done solely through a notary. Here are the general steps involved in changing or removing a surname from academic documents:

Prepare a Deed Poll or Affidavit: You will need to prepare a legal document known as a Deed Poll or an Affidavit stating your intention to change or remove your surname from your academic records. This document should clearly explain the reasons for the change and provide details about your old and new names.

Notarize the Document: After preparing the Deed Poll or Affidavit, you should have it notarized by a registered notary public. Notarization is essential to authenticate the document.

Publish a Gazette Notification: In some cases, you may be required to publish a Gazette Notification regarding the change of name. This is typically done after notarization.

Court Process (Optional): While notarization and gazette notification are often sufficient for many practical purposes, if you want to change your name on official academic records, you may need to go through a court process. This involves filing a petition in the appropriate court (usually the jurisdictional Civil Court or District Court) to officially change or remove your surname.

Provide Supporting Documents: Along with the court petition (if applicable), you should attach supporting documents such as your notarized Deed Poll or Affidavit, academic certificates and records, identification documents, and any other relevant documentation that the court may require.

Court Order (if applicable): If you go through the court process, the court will issue an official order approving the name change or removal of the surname. This court order is essential for changing your name on official records.

Notify Academic Institutions: After obtaining the court order (if applicable), you should notify your academic institutions about the name change or removal of your surname. Provide them with a copy of the court order for their records.

Update Academic Records: Work with your academic institutions to update your academic records and certificates to reflect the approved name change. This may involve submitting the court order and other necessary documents to the academic institutions.

It's important to note that the process may vary slightly depending on the specific requirements of your academic institutions and local regulations. Consulting with a legal expert or an attorney in Bangalore who specializes in name changes and documentation amendments can provide you with guidance tailored to your situation and help ensure that the name change is legally recognized on your academic documents.

My mother is a joint owner of a property. The original owner of that property is my mother's father who had died in 1998. After his death, my mother, her elder brother and her mother became the joint owners. My mother's elder brother and her mother were trying to hand over the entire property to a promoter and for which my mother gave strong objection. Yesterday, such Suit was duly admitted. My mother will move her interim injunction application tomorrow because third party is now trying to take physical possession of the property and also trying demolish the same. 

My mother filed a Writ Petition before the Calcutta High Court prior to filing of that Suit for declaration and in that Writ Petition on 14.09.2023 The Hon'ble Justice of Calcutta High Court has directed the Local Police Station to provide adequate police protection to my mother and me so that we can return to my mother's father's property and the entire process will be videographed by the police. The order copy was communicated to the Local Police Station on 15.09.2023 for immediate compliance.

So, now my question is that can my mother get interim injunction against the third party tomorrow because some Lawyers saying that your mother is not in possession of the property so such injuction will not be allowed. Some other Lawyers saying Yes, your mother will get such injunction because, title, share, right and everything belongs to your mother, so, your mother may not be in possession of the property due to some disputes but to protect such rights she can get interim injunction. 

So, I am very confused at this time what law says in this regard because interim injunction will be moved tomorrow should we tell everything to the Court in a fair manner or should we supress one thing by saying that my mother is in the possession of the property. 
We are very concerned about the grant of such interim injunction.

Pls suggest me.

Thanks and Regards.									
									 
									
									Dear Client,
Injunctions are legal remedies issued by a court to prevent a party from taking certain actions. In this case, your mother wants to obtain an interim injunction to prevent the third party from taking possession or demolishing the property.
The grant of an interim injunction typically depends on several factors, including the merits of the case, the balance of convenience, and whether irreparable harm would be caused to your mother if the injunction is not granted. Whether or not your mother is in physical possession of the property may affect the court's decision, but it may not be the only determining factor.
Here are some considerations:
Title and Rights: If your mother can establish that she has a valid title and rights to the property, the court may be more inclined to grant an injunction, even if she is not in physical possession. The court may consider the legal rights and interests associated with the property.
Balance of Convenience: The court will weigh the potential harm to your mother against the harm that the third party might suffer if the injunction is granted. If the court believes that your mother's rights and interests are more substantial, it may grant the injunction.
Merits of the Case: The court may also consider the merits of your mother's case, including the validity of the sale deed and whether it was legally executed. If there are significant legal issues in her favor, it could influence the court's decision.
Fair and Full Disclosure: It's generally advisable to provide the court with all relevant information and not to suppress any facts. Courts often appreciate full and honest disclosure. Misrepresentation of facts can have serious legal consequences.

Publish a Name Change Notice:

Bank Accounts: Inform your bank about the name change and provide them with the necessary documents.

In a mutual consent divorce petition in India, the process typically involves two motions or appearances before the court. Here's a general overview of the process:
First Motion:
Both spouses (petitioners) jointly file the divorce petition, along with the mutual consent affidavit, before the family court.

During the first motion, you are not required to appear before the court together; instead, the petition and affidavits are submitted to the court through your respective lawyers.

Cooling-Off Period:
After the first motion is recorded, there is a mandatory six-month cooling-off period.

Second Motion:

Both spouses are required to appear before the court together for the second motion.
During the second motion, the court will verify if the parties continue to be in mutual agreement for divorce.
If both parties reconfirm their mutual consent to divorce, the court may grant the divorce decree.
Regarding the financial settlement, it's common for parties to discuss and agree on the financial aspects, including any settlement amount, division of assets, or alimony, before or during the divorce proceedings. Appeal Process: Since the pensioner has already filed an appeal in the High Court, the outcome of the appeal will be crucial. If the conviction is overturned or if there are substantial legal errors in the lower court's judgment, it could impact the pension withdrawal decision.

Special Leave Petitions (SLPs) are generally permissible in the Supreme Court of India as a discretionary remedy. However, the specific circumstances under which an SLP can be filed, especially after other legal remedies have been exhausted, can vary based on the facts of the case and the applicable laws. Here's a general overview:
Civil Appeal: A civil appeal is a common legal remedy to challenge a decision of a lower court or tribunal, including the National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (NCDRC). If a civil appeal has already been filed and decided, and a review petition has also been dismissed, it means that the usual appellate remedies have been exhausted.
Curative Petition: A curative petition is a rare and exceptional remedy available in India. It is typically used when a petitioner believes that there has been a gross miscarriage of justice, and it is the last resort for redressal after all other remedies, including appeals and reviews, have been exhausted.
Special Leave Petition (SLP): An SLP is a discretionary remedy that allows the Supreme Court of India to grant special permission to hear an appeal against any judgment, decree, determination, sentence, or order in any cause or matter. It is not an appeal by right but is granted at the discretion of the Supreme Court.
In your scenario, if the curative petition arising out of a civil appeal and a review petition has been dismissed by the Supreme Court, it suggests that the petitioner has already exhausted most available remedies.
However, the possibility of filing an SLP after the dismissal of a curative petition would depend on the specific facts of the case, whether there are any exceptional circumstances, and whether the Supreme Court is inclined to grant special leave. The Supreme Court has the authority to entertain an SLP if it believes that the case raises substantial questions of law or issues of public importance.

Reinstatement of Pension: In many legal systems, when a person is acquitted on appeal and their conviction is overturned, their pension is typically reinstated. This means that they should receive their pension from the date of acquittal onwards.
Arrears Payment: In cases where the pension was wrongfully withheld during the period of conviction, the individual may be entitled to arrears for the period of withdrawal. This would be the amount they would have received as pension during that time.
Minimum Pension: The existence and amount of a minimum pension, if any, would depend on the specific pension scheme or government regulations. Some pension schemes may have provisions for a minimum pension amount that must be paid regardless of the circumstances.

data:
Minimum tenaments are required to register Apartment Declaration in Maharashtra.

Advocate, A.P.Loganathan, Madras High Court

For more clarification contact me, getting details from path legal or Google site
										
									 
									
									Dear Client,
Minimum 10 tenants are required. 
Things to be included in your Apartment Declaration:
Details such as the description of the land on which building and improvements are or are to be located, Apartment number of each apartment along with a statement of location, number of rooms and immediate common area to which the apartment shall have access to, Description of common area and facilities, Statement of Purpose for which building and apartment shall be used along with restrictions.
Thank you										
									 
									
									In Maharashtra, as of my last knowledge update in September 2021, the Maharashtra Ownership of Flats Act, 1963 (MOFA) governs the registration of apartment declarations for multi-unit residential buildings. The Act defines the rules and requirements for property developers and societies when creating and registering apartment ownership.

While there may not be a specific mention of a minimum number of tenements or units required to register an apartment declaration in the MOFA, certain conditions need to be met:

Minimum Area: Usually, each apartment in a building must have a separate and exclusive area for it to be eligible for registration under MOFA. The Act does not specify a minimum size, but each unit should be a self-contained dwelling.

Common Areas: The Act also deals with common areas and facilities in the building, such as passages, staircases, and other amenities. It's important to define and allocate these common areas and facilities in the apartment declaration.

Formation of a Cooperative Housing Society: In many cases, the formation of a cooperative housing society is required to register the apartment declaration. The society can consist of all the apartment owners, and they collectively manage the common areas and facilities.

Developer's Obligations: Property developers are generally responsible for drafting the apartment declaration and providing all the necessary documents to the society or apartment owners for registration.

While there may not be a specific minimum number of tenements mentioned in the law, the key is to ensure that the property complies with the provisions of the MOFA and that the apartment declaration clearly defines the rights and responsibilities of each apartment owner and the management of common areas.

Please note that laws and regulations can change over time, and it's important to consult with a legal professional or the local housing authority for the most up-to-date information and guidance on registering apartment declarations in Maharashtra.

									Dear Client, 
 Under Article 351, CSR [Rule 8, CCS (Pension) Rules, 1972] future good conduct is an implied condition of the grant of every pension and Government has the right to withhold or withdraw a pension or any part of it if the pensioner is convicted of a serious crime or found guilty of grave misconduct. 									Obtaining a possession certificate for ancestral land where you have been in possession for several decades is a complex legal matter and can vary significantly based on the jurisdiction, local laws, and circumstances. While I can provide some general information, it's crucial to consult with a local attorney who specializes in property law in your specific area for advice tailored to your situation. Here are some general points to consider:

Adverse Possession Laws: Some jurisdictions have laws related to adverse possession, which may allow a person to claim legal ownership of land if they have possessed it openly, continuously, and without challenge for a specified period (which can range from several years to several decades). However, the requirements for adverse possession can vary widely, and it's essential to consult with an attorney to determine if this applies to your situation.

Land Records and Documentation: Gather all available documents related to the property, such as old land deeds, surveys, tax records, and any other documents that may establish your family's historical connection to the land.

Witness Statements: If possible, obtain statements from witnesses who can attest to the fact that your family has been in possession of the land for many decades. These statements can support your claim of continuous possession.

Consult an Attorney: Consult with a local attorney who specializes in property and land disputes. They can review the specifics of your case, assess the applicable laws, and guide you on the best course of action.

Prescription Laws: In some jurisdictions, there are laws related to prescription rights, which may allow you to establish certain rights over the land due to long-term possession. Again, the requirements can vary, so legal advice is essential.

Land Records Updates: Some jurisdictions allow for the updating of land records to reflect the current possession. An attorney can help you with the process of updating land records if it is possible in your area.

Land Survey: Consider having a professional land survey conducted to precisely determine the boundaries and extent of the land you possess.

Dispute Resolution: Be prepared for potential disputes or legal challenges from other claimants or parties who may have an interest in the land. Your attorney can help you navigate these challenges.

Remember that property laws can be complex and subject to change, and they vary by location. Consulting with a knowledgeable attorney who is familiar with the property laws in your specific jurisdiction is crucial to understanding your options and pursuing a course of action that is legally sound and appropriate for your situation.										
									 
									
									Dear Client,

As per the rule of adverse possession,  If you have peacefully possessed a piece of land for atleast 20 years then you can be the owner of such land. Since, you say 4-5 decades it means 40-50 years, get all the evidence to prove peaceful possession and you  can be the owner. The evidence could include testimony by neighbours, tax payment slips, no previous cases on that property etc. 
Thank you

headline: Ancestral property inheritance rights of grand children.
data:
Do grandchildren still have rights on ancestral property after 2005 amendment of the supreme court? 

Our ancestral property from my mother's side was partitioned in September 2004 when my grand father was alive. My mother who is not educated signed on the partition deed without being aware of the consequences and did not get anything in her name. I was a minor and did not have knowledge about the situation. Now as far as we are concerned we don't have a legal case in 2023 since supreme court has put 31st December 2004 as the cutoff date to challenge partition deeds with respect to woman's rights on property inheritance. My mother herself did not know about what she signed on until 10 years ago. Once we were aware we were not in a position financially to take my uncles to court who were the primary culprits in defrauding my mother. 

Now in 2023 my grandfather who was also not aware of the full extent of what he signed on in 2004 is no longer with us. What are my rights as a grandchild? Can I still challenge the partition deed after 19 years? I have contacted few lawyers who have given different answers without clearly answering how the case will affect us with respect to statute of limitations of 12 years and supreme court amendment of 2005. I want to take my uncles to court but there will be no point if the case can be dismissed for the reasons stated above. 

Please give your valuable opinions.  									
									 
									
									Dear Client,
The limitation period to challenge a partition is 12 years.
Grandchildren have to receive from their parents' share only. They do not have a separate share of their own. So, you cannot initiate proceedings in your own name. However, you can do that in your mother's name. You  can a file a case challenging the deed being a fraud since your mother is uneducated she did not understand the contents of the deed ( If the opposite side is able to prove that your mother was aware, then your case will be lost). 
The 12 year limitation period is from the date of adverse claim to the petitioner. Adverse claim means when the claimant possesses a property interest in the financial asset and such right of the claimant is violated at the hands of other people by holding, transferring, or dealing with the financial asset. Citing that your mother was uneducated and that you also learnt about it only now ( saying 2 3 years ago might prove disadvantageous), you cn very well explain the cause of delay. 
The decision of whether there is unreasonable delay or not will be of the Court itself.
Hope this helps.
Thank you										
									 
									
									Yes they have rights . click										
									 
									
									Dear Sir,
What does the grandparent's property law in India state? Does the grandson own the right to the property?
All property's owned by a Hindu person devolves onto his class one legal heir's. 

Now to the specific scenario's in ur example (for sake of convenience I'm presuming your grandfather has only one legal heir)

Senario1: The property is self acquired by your Grandfather, in such case upon his demise intestate (without a will) the property would devolve upon ur Father and not you. In case your father passes away before your grandfather then in such case it would devolve upon you, your mother and ur siblings equally.

Scenario 2: the property in question is self acquired by ur grandfather father ( ur great grand farther) - would devolve same as scenario 1.

Scenario 3: the property in question is self acquired by ur grandfather grand father ( ur great great grand farther) - would devolve same as scenario 1.

Scenario 4: the property in question is self acquired by ur grandfathers great grand father ( ur great great great grand farther) - then in such a case you would be entitled to the property by birth as it becomes ur ancestral property.

To give you more clarity on the concept of Ancestral Property's : any property which passes undivided down 4 generations of male lineage is called ancestral property. The right to such property acquires at birth unlike other laws of inheritance where right arises upon the death of the the owner.

Hope this brings some clarity to your question and your sense of entitlements.
Meaning of ancestral property  in India-An ancestral property means a propertywhich is devolved upon heirs by the 3 generations above them; father, father's fatheror father's fathers' father. ... That means when a coparcener acquires his share inancestral property than he can make a will to that share and bequest it.
Meaning of ancestral property in India-An ancestral property means a property which is devolved upon heirs by the 3 generations above them; father, father’s father or father’s fathers’ father. It passes to the next three generations.
Meaning of will-A will means a document in which a person specifies the method to be applied in management and distribution of properties after his death.
The basic principle involved is that the property should be four generations old. The right to use and acquire property is accrued by persons through birth itself. The division of property is per stripes i.e. that share of one generation is calculated first than the share of successive generations is subdivided according to share of their predecessor. These basic elements are for governing majorly the Hindus.
If A inherits property, whether movable or immovable, from his father or father’s father, or father’s father’sfather, it is ancestral property as regards his male issue. If A has no son, son’s son, or son’s son’s son in existence at the time when he inherits the property, he holds the property as absolute owner thereof, and he can deal with it as he pleases . A person inheriting property from his three immediate paternal ancestors holds it, and must hold it, in coparcenary with his sons, sons’ sons and sons’ sons’ sons but as regards other relations he holds it and is entitled to hold it, as his absolute property.”[1]
Now answer to the question is that that will to ancestral property is not entirelyillegal. That means when a coparcener acquires his share in ancestral property than he can make a will to that share and bequest it. However will shall be executed after the death of the testator and if the coparcener before acquiring a share makes a will than that will be illegal. Share in ancestral property will be inherited by coparceners. So he can make a will to his share in ancestral property.As whatever he acquires is his share now and he can dispose his assets according to his wishes.
Surender Kumar vs Dhani Ram CS (OS) No.1737/2012 decided on 18th January, 2016 Hon’ble Mr. J. Valmiki Mehta of Delhi High Court ruled-
If a person dies after passing of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 and there is no HUF existing at the time of the death of such a person, inheritance of an immovable property of such a person by his successors-in-interest is no doubt inheritance of an ‘ancestral’ property but the inheritance is as a self acquired property in the hands of the successor and not as an HUF property although the successor(s) indeed inherits ‘ancestral’ property i.e. a property belonging to his paternal ancestor.

									Dear Client,
A perjury petition, filed under Section 340 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC), is a legal action taken against a witness who is alleged to have given false evidence during a civil case. Here are the general steps involved in such a case:
Filing of Perjury Petition:
You, as the petitioner, file a perjury petition before the court where the alleged false evidence was given.
The petition should detail the specific instances of false evidence provided by the witness and should be supported by relevant documents and evidence.
Notice to the Accused Witness:
Once the perjury petition is filed, the court will issue notice to the accused witness, informing them of the perjury allegations and asking them to respond.
Response by Accused Witness:
The accused witness will have the opportunity to file a response or counter-affidavit, defending themselves against the perjury allegations.
Evidence Stage:
If necessary, both parties (petitioner and accused witness) will be allowed to present evidence to support their respective positions. This may include documents, affidavits, or other evidence.
Cross-Examination:
Both parties may have the opportunity to cross-examine each other's witnesses during the evidence stage. Cross-examination is a critical phase to establish the credibility of the evidence and the statements made by the accused witness.
Arguments:
After the evidence stage and cross-examination, both parties will have the opportunity to present their arguments before the court. This involves explaining their positions and presenting legal reasoning.
Judgment:
The court will consider the evidence, arguments, and counter-arguments presented by both parties.
The court will then deliver its judgment, either finding the accused witness guilty of perjury or dismissing the perjury petition if it is not proven.
Penalty:
If the court finds the accused witness guilty of perjury, they may impose a penalty or punishment as provided under the law. Penalties may include imprisonment or fines.
Thank You										
									 
									
									Filing a perjury petition against a witness in a civil case is a legal process that typically involves several stages. The exact procedures can vary depending on your jurisdiction, so it's essential to consult with your attorney who can provide guidance specific to your case. However, here are the general steps involved:

Filing the Perjury Petition:

You (the petitioner) file a perjury petition against the witness (the respondent) who you believe has provided false testimony or evidence in your civil case.
Your petition should clearly state the instances of perjury, including the specific statements or evidence that you believe to be false.
Notice to the Respondent:

After filing the petition, the court typically issues a notice to the respondent, informing them of the perjury allegations and providing them with an opportunity to respond.
Respondent's Reply:

The respondent has the opportunity to file a reply or counter-affidavit in response to your perjury petition. They may deny the allegations and present their defense.
Evidence Stage:

Once both parties have filed their respective pleadings (the perjury petition and the respondent's reply), the court may schedule an evidence stage.
During this stage, both parties may present evidence to support their respective positions. This can include documents, affidavits, witness statements, and any other relevant evidence.
Cross-Examination:

If there are witnesses involved, including the respondent, both parties may have the opportunity to cross-examine each other's witnesses.
Cross-examination involves asking questions to challenge the credibility and reliability of the witness's testimony.
Arguments:

After the evidence stage and cross-examination, both parties may have the opportunity to present their arguments before the court.
You and the respondent will have the chance to explain your positions, cite legal precedents, and provide legal arguments supporting your case.
Final Judgment:

After considering the evidence, arguments, and legal points presented by both parties, the court will make a final judgment regarding the perjury allegations.
The court may dismiss the perjury petition if it determines that perjury was not committed, or it may find the witness guilty of perjury if the evidence supports such a finding.
Penalties for perjury can vary but may include fines, imprisonment, or other sanctions, depending on your jurisdiction's laws.
It's crucial to work closely with your attorney throughout this process to ensure that your perjury petition is properly prepared and presented to the court. Additionally, your attorney can guide you through the various stages and help you build a strong case to support your allegations of perjury.

A  possession certificate is a legal document that serves as evidence of ownership or possession of a particular asset or property. The possession certificate must be obtained from the local authority where the property is located. The possession certificate is valid for one year from the date of issue. 
You can easily apply for your Land Possession Certificate from the Tahsildar Office (in rural areas) or Revenue Divisional Officer (for urban areas). 
All you must do is follow the below-mentioned steps: 
Step 1: Visit the concerned Tahsildar Office (if your property is in a rural area) or Revenue Divisional Office (if your property is in an urban area) and obtain the form to get your Land Possession Certificate. Step 2: Fill out your personal details and the details of your property in the form. 
Step 3: Submit the form along with the requisite documents- income certificate, passport-size photos, Ration Card, Aadhaar Card, proof of ownership or property, etc. to the concerned officer. 
Step 4: Once you have submitted the form and the required documents, you will get an acknowledgement along with an application number. You can track your application status using this application number. 
Step 5: A technical officer will visit your property for inspection. The property will further be reviewed by the higher officials and the city planner. 									In Maharashtra, obtaining a possession certificate for your land or property can be a useful step in documenting your ownership and possession of the property. While it may not directly address issues of neighbor encroachment or property document corrections, having a possession certificate can serve as supporting evidence in potential legal disputes. Here are the steps to get a possession certificate in Maharashtra:

Visit the Local Revenue Office: You should visit the local revenue office (Tahsildar's office) in the area where your property is located. This is where you can apply for a possession certificate.

Application Form: Inquire at the revenue office about the specific application form required for a possession certificate. You will need to fill out this form, providing details about the property, its location, your ownership, and your possession of the property.

Supporting Documents: You may be asked to submit supporting documents along with your application. These documents can include property tax receipts, electricity bills, water bills, or any other documents that demonstrate your possession of the property.

Verification and Inspection: After submitting your application, a revenue officer may conduct a verification and inspection of the property to confirm your possession.

Publication of Notice: In some cases, a notice may be published in a local newspaper to invite objections from the public. If there are no objections within a specified period, the possession certificate may be issued.

Possession Certificate Issuance: Once the verification and any necessary procedures are completed, and there are no objections or disputes, the revenue authorities may issue a possession certificate.

Registration: The possession certificate should be registered in your name with the local authorities. This ensures that it is officially recorded and can be used as a legal document.

Regarding whether obtaining a possession certificate is worth it for avoiding neighbor encroachment, it is a step that can help strengthen your claim to the property. However, it may not be the only step necessary. To address neighbor encroachment and property document corrections, you should consider the following:

Document Corrections: If there are errors or discrepancies in your property documents, work on getting those corrected through the appropriate legal channels.

Property Disputes Act: In cases of property disputes, you may also consider utilizing the provisions of the Maharashtra Land Revenue Code and the Maharashtra Land Revenue (Dispute Resolution and Settlement of Rights) Act, 1996.

Loan Repayment: Ensure that you have fully repaid the mortgage loan, including the principal amount and any accrued interest, to the bank or lending institution.

Request a No Objection Certificate (NOC): Contact your bank or lending institution and request a No Objection Certificate (NOC) or a Mortgage Release Letter. This document confirms that the loan has been fully repaid and that the bank has no further claim on your property.

Property Inspection: The bank may inspect the property to verify its condition and ensure that there are no encroachments, illegal constructions, or other issues that could affect the property's value or security.

Legal Documentation: Once the bank is satisfied with the repayment, they will provide you with the NOC or Mortgage Release Letter. This document should be on the bank's letterhead and signed by an authorized representative.

Stamp Duty: In some jurisdictions, you may need to pay stamp duty on the NOC or Mortgage Release Letter, depending on local laws and regulations.

Registration: In some cases, you may be required to register the NOC or Mortgage Release Letter with the local land registry office to ensure that it is legally recognized and recorded as evidence of the mortgage release.

Notification to Credit Bureaus: Ensure that the bank reports the mortgage release to credit bureaus to update your credit record accordingly, reflecting that the loan has been paid off.

Retrieval of Original Documents: After completing the necessary formalities, you should receive the original property documents that were held as security by the bank. These documents may include the title deed, sale deed, and any other relevant property-related documents.

Keep Records: It's crucial to maintain copies of all documents related to the mortgage release, including the NOC or Mortgage Release Letter, payment receipts, and any correspondence with the bank. These documents serve as evidence that the mortgage has been released.

Notify Relevant Authorities: Depending on local requirements, you may need to notify other relevant authorities, such as the municipal corporation or housing society, about the mortgage release.

Please note that the specific procedures and requirements for releasing a mortgage may vary by jurisdiction and may depend on the terms of your mortgage agreement with the bank. 4. Can an intermediary sell a land given to him by actual owner under West Bengal land reform act?? 

Please 🙏 answer these questions serially 									
									 
									
									Dear Client,
The West Bengal Land Reforms Act, 1955, is a comprehensive piece of legislation that governs land reforms in the state of West Bengal, India. It introduced various provisions to regulate land ownership, land use, and tenancy rights. To answer your questions:

Intermediary or Agent as Landowner: Under the West Bengal Land Reforms Act, intermediaries or agents generally cannot be the owners of agricultural land. The Act aimed to abolish the zamindari system and vested ownership rights in the actual tillers of the land. Intermediaries or agents would typically not qualify as the actual cultivators or tillers unless they meet specific criteria outlined in the Act.

Occupier Registering as Raiyat Sthitiban: The Act allows for the recognition and registration of raiyats and under-raiyats who are in actual possession of land. If someone is an occupier and meets the criteria for being recognized as a raiyat or under-raiyat under the Act, they may be eligible to register as such. However, this recognition would be subject to the conditions and qualifications outlined in the Act.

Occupier Registering Land for an Intermediary: Generally, the Act does not permit an occupier to register land they occupy in favor of an intermediary or agent. The Act's primary objective is to vest land rights in the actual cultivators or tillers (raiayats and under-raiyats) and to abolish intermediaries.

Intermediary Selling Land: Under the West Bengal Land Reforms Act, intermediaries generally cannot sell land given to them by the actual owner. The Act aimed to break the intermediaries' hold on agricultural land and distribute landownership to the actual tillers. Intermediaries had their rights limited by the Act, and their ability to sell land to others was restricted.

headline: Writ of mandanus issued to a public authority is it compulsary to do
data:
A writ of mandamus is issued to an executive authority by high court then ಹೇಳು can do the work in what time period									
									 
									
									It is compulsory to comply with mandamus order passed by High Court. If not complied with, the same will be deemed to be contempt of court and the contemnor may be put to imprisonment for violation of the order suo motu or on a contempt application filed by any person within 1 year of such contempt.
Regards,
Bidhayak Acharyya
Advocate										
									 
									
									Dear Client,
‘Mandamus’ means ‘we command’. It is issued by the Court to direct a public authority to perform the legal duties which it has not or refused to perform. It can be issued by the Court against a public official, public corporation, tribunal, inferior court or the government. It cannot be issued against a private individual or body, the President or Governors of States or against a working Chief Justices. Further, it cannot be issued in the following circumstances:
The duty in question is discretionary and not mandatory. 
For the performance of a non-statutory function. 
Performance of the duty involves rights of purely private nature.
Where such direction involves violation of any law. 
Where there is any other remedy available under the law.
The writ of mandamus is issued for keeping the public authorities within their jurisdiction while exercising public functions. The object of mandamus is the prevention of disorder emanating from failure of justice that is required to be granted in all cases where there is no specific remedy established in law. It cannot be issued when the government or public official has no duty to perform under the law. 
A writ petition seeking mandamus must be filed by a person in good faith and who has an interest in the performance of the duty by the public authority. The person seeking mandamus must have a legal right to do so and also must have demanded the performance of the duty and it is refused by the authority.
In All India Tea Trading Co. v. S.D.O. (AIR 1962 Ass 20) case, the Land Acquisition Officer erroneously refused to pay the interest on compensation amount. A writ of mandamus was issued against the Land Acquisition Officer directing him to reconsider the application for the payment of interest.
In Suganmal v. State of M.P. (AIR 1965 SC 1740) case, the petitioner (person who files the writ petition) filed for issuing a writ of mandamus to direct the respondent (opposite party in the writ) for refunding tax. The Supreme Court held that where an assessment order was set aside and the rules concerned did not provide for refund of tax levied, a writ of mandamus cannot be issued. The proper remedy is filing a suit for claiming the refund.
Thank You

If a husband and wife are living together under the same roof but do not wish to continue their marriage, and one party seeks a divorce while the other does not agree, the legal process can become complex. The outcome will depend on the specific circumstances and the laws of the jurisdiction in which they reside.
Here's an overview of potential scenarios:
Mutual Consent Divorce: If both parties agree to divorce, they can file for a mutual consent divorce. This is usually the quickest and most straightforward way to end a marriage.
Contested Divorce: If one party wants a divorce and the other does not, it can lead to a contested divorce. In such cases, the spouse seeking the divorce will have to prove grounds for divorce recognized under the law. The grounds for divorce can vary depending on the jurisdiction but may include reasons like adultery, cruelty, desertion, mental disorder, and more.
Adultery: If one spouse can prove that the other engaged in extramarital affairs, it can be grounds for divorce.
Cruelty: Suffering physical or mental cruelty at the hands of a spouse can be a valid reason for divorce.
Desertion: If one spouse abandons the other without a valid reason for a specified period, it can be considered desertion.
Mental Disorder: If one spouse is suffering from a severe mental disorder that makes living together impossible, it can be grounds for divorce.
Legal Separation: In some cases, couples may choose legal separation instead of divorce. Legal separation allows them to live separately and make legal arrangements for property, child custody, and support without officially ending the marriage.
No-Fault Divorce: Some jurisdictions have adopted "no-fault" divorce laws, where neither party has to prove wrongdoing. They can simply state that the marriage has irretrievably broken down.
Waiting Periods: Some jurisdictions have mandatory waiting periods before granting a divorce. During this time, the couple may be required to attend counseling or mediation.

It's essential to consult with a family law advocate in your specific jurisdiction to understand the applicable laws and procedures. State-specific laws and regulations: Different states in India may have their own rules and regulations governing the operation of heavy machinery in construction and mining activities. These laws may cover issues such as safety standards, environmental regulations, and licensing.

Environmental Laws: Depending on the nature of the construction or mining project, environmental laws and regulations may also apply, especially if the machinery's operation has environmental implications.

headline: SCHEDULE OF THE PROPERTY
data:

The schedule and boundaries of any property keeps changing time to time like nee Khata number or latest conversation done etc., except the measurements of the property. When making a fresh transaction like Sale Agreement, Sale Deed or Confirmation Deed in respect of a property, what are the precautions to be taken care of which making such new additions in the Schedule of a Property and what are the mistakes to be avoided.									
									 
									
									Dear Client,
It will be better to check with the authorities regarding the details of the schedule of the property before preparing a Sale deed. 
Detailed:  The property schedule should be as detailed as possible in the Sale deed regarding the surrounding plots, owner of the plot to be sold etc. 
Free from encumbrances: Make sure that the taxes are well-paid and there are no dues regarding water bill, electricity bill etc. 
 It’s crucial to register the schedule of property in the sale deed. Upon purchase, the vendor provides the necessary documents to the Vendee, who should safely store and acknowledge the receipts.
Property Division: The division of property among co-owners is facilitated using the schedule in the sale deed, along with mutation agreements signed by all parties.
Consistency with Sale Agreement: The details in the schedule of the property should align with those in the sale agreement. If discrepancies exist, a separate designated document may be required for clarification.
Conveyance Document: The conveyance document should incorporate the ‘Schedule A’ of the property, providing a clear and mandatory explanation.
It is also advisable to have all the documents ready in hand.
Thank you

If a revision petition was filed in the National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (NCRDC) against the Tamil Nadu State Consumer Court's decision, and the NCRDC has now passed a final order in your favor, it is generally less common for a stay order to be issued after a final order has been issued. However, it is not impossible, and it depends on various factors, including the specific circumstances of the case and the arguments presented by the opposing party.

Here are some points to consider:

Grounds for Stay: In order for a court to issue a stay order, the opposing party would typically need to demonstrate strong and compelling grounds. Common grounds for seeking a stay include the risk of irreparable harm, errors in the judgment, or issues related to the execution of the judgment.

Appeal Process: If the opposing party wishes to challenge the final order, they may follow the proper legal procedure to appeal the decision. The appeal process involves presenting their case before a higher court, and they may request a stay during this appeal process.

Legal Representation: It's important for both parties to have legal representation during any further legal proceedings. Competent attorneys can present arguments and counterarguments, which will influence the court's decision regarding a stay order.

Timing: The timing of the request for a stay is crucial. Typically, requests for stays are made promptly after an unfavorable judgment is rendered. Once a final order has been issued, it can be more challenging to obtain a stay.

Court's Discretion: Ultimately, whether a court grants a stay order is at the discretion of the court. The court will consider the merits of the case, the potential harm or benefit to both parties, and the interests of justice.

Consult an Attorney: If you are concerned about the possibility of a stay order, it is advisable to consult with an attorney who specializes in consumer law or appeals. They can provide you with guidance on how to respond to any stay application and can represent your interests in court.

It's important to note that each case is unique, and the outcome can vary depending on the specific facts and legal arguments involved. Asset and Liabilities Affidavit without Case Number:

In many legal proceedings, including maintenance cases under Section 125 of the CrPC (Criminal Procedure Code), an Asset and Liabilities Affidavit is a required document to assess the financial status of the parties involved. While it's ideal to have the case number mentioned on the affidavit for easy reference, the absence of the case number alone does not necessarily invalidate the document.
What is more critical is whether the affidavit contains accurate and complete information regarding the assets and liabilities of the party. If there are inaccuracies or if relevant information is missing, you may need to address these issues in your appeal.
Obtaining the Asset and Liabilities Affidavit with Case Number:

Appeal: If you believe there are legal errors in the judgment or order that need to be addressed, you may file an appeal in the appropriate higher court, which is usually the Sessions Court.
Review Petition: Review petitions are typically filed in the same court that issued the judgment or order. They are used when there is an error apparent on the face of the record or when new evidence that was not available at the time of the original judgment comes to light.

headline: What is the limitation period for review in High Court in revision
data:
Sir/Madam,

In 2022 I filed a case Under Section 125 of CrPC against my husband for my monthly maintenance and the said case was disposed of in July, 2023 by giving final order of monthly maintenance of Rs. 10000/- but my husband challenged such order before the Hon'ble Calcutta High Court by way of Criminal Revision. The Hon'ble Justice has been pleased to dispose of the said revision on 31.08.2023 with certain directions which have gone in favour of my husband and for which, I have been seriously affected. In that matter, I did not get any notice. I have perused the order and I have got to know that many points were suppressed by my husband in that revision and got favourable order. So, now I have taken decision to file Review Application before the Hon'ble Calcutta High Court.

So, I just want to know that what is the actual time period for filing such Review Application before the Hon'ble High Court in Criminal Revision matters. Please inform me urgently. 

Thanks and Regards. 									
									 
									
									Dear Client, 
The limitation period for filing a review petition before the High Court is 30 days from the date of the previous order. However, please take notice that if you can show sufficient cause that you were unaware of the order and that you had received no such notice, you can be excused for such delay. Please take an action urgently.
Thankyou										
									 
									
									The time limit for filing a review petition in the Calcutta High Court or any High Court in India is governed by the rules and provisions of the Civil Procedure Code (CPC) and the applicable High Court rules. However, it's important to note that a review petition typically cannot be filed as a matter of right, and there are specific grounds on which you can seek a review.

In the case of a criminal revision matter, you may want to consult with a qualified attorney in Kolkata who specializes in family and criminal law to understand the specific rules and procedures applicable in your jurisdiction.

Typically, in civil matters, including review petitions, the time limit for filing a review application is governed by Order 47, Rule 1 of the CPC, which states:

"Any person considering himself aggrieved—

(a) by a decree or order from which an appeal is allowed, but from which no appeal has been preferred,

(b) by a decree or order from which no appeal is allowed, or

(c) by a decision on a reference from a Court of Small Causes,

and who, from the discovery of new and important matter or evidence which, after the exercise of due diligence, was not within his knowledge or could not be produced by him at the time when the decree was passed or order made, or on account of some mistake or error apparent on the face of the record, or for any other sufficient reason, desires to obtain a review of the decree passed or order made against him, may apply for a review of judgment to the Court which passed the decree or made the order."

This means that if you believe there are grounds for review, such as the discovery of new and important evidence or an error apparent on the face of the record, you may be able to file a review petition.

However, the specific time limit for filing a review petition in your case may depend on the High Court rules and local regulations. Therefore, it's crucial to consult with a local attorney who can provide you with accurate information and guidance on the time frame for filing a review application in the Calcutta High Court in the context of a criminal revision matter. Your attorney will be able to assess the specific circumstances of your case and advise you accordingly.

3. Clarify Your Position:

4. Attach Supporting Documentation:
Include any supporting documentation that demonstrates your compliance with tax laws or that substantiates your argument against the penalty.
This may include copies of relevant tax returns, financial statements, correspondence with tax authorities, or any other documents that support your case.
5. Request for Reconsideration:
Politely request that the tax authority reconsider the penalty assessment in light of the new information you have provided and the judgment in the Checkmate Services Pvt. Ltd. case.
6. Offer to Cooperate:
Express your willingness to cooperate fully with the tax authority in resolving this matter and providing any additional information they may require.
7. Closing Statement:
Conclude your letter by thanking the tax authority for their attention to this matter and expressing your hope for a fair and equitable resolution.
8. Sincerely:

However, please note that tax matters are highly specific, and you should consult with a qualified tax attorney or tax professional who can provide personalized advice and draft a reply tailored to your particular circumstances. Here are some arguments that you may consider:

Substantial Compliance: Argue that you have substantially complied with the tax laws and regulations. You can provide evidence to support your claim that any discrepancies were unintentional or due to genuine errors.

Reasonable Cause: Demonstrate that there was a reasonable cause for the non-compliance. This could include factors beyond your control that led to the issue or non-compliance, such as reliance on professional advice, technical glitches, or unforeseen circumstances.

Reliance on Precedent: If your CIT appeal was dismissed due to a judgment that was issued after your appeal was filed, you may argue that you relied in good faith on the existing legal precedents and were unaware of the change in interpretation.

No Willful Neglect: Show that there was no willful neglect on your part to comply with the tax laws. Explain any steps you took to rectify the situation as soon as you became aware of the issue.

Quantum of Penalty: Contest the quantum of the penalty imposed. Argue that the penalty is excessive and disproportionate to the alleged non-compliance.

Due Process: Ensure that the tax authorities followed due process and provided you with a proper opportunity to present your case before imposing the penalty.

Legal Interpretation: Seek a legal interpretation of the relevant tax provisions and regulations to support your position.

There shall be no tax implication in the hands of your parents . As any gift received (amount transfered without consideration) by father from son is not taxable under the Income tax Act.

Provision of Section 56(2)(x)

As per the provision of Section 56(2)(x) if the value of gifts received exceeds Rs. 50,000 in a year, then such amount is taxed as income in the hands of the receiver. headline: “SALE DEED” or “ABSOLUTE SALE DEED”

Dear Advocate,
I thank you for spending your valuable time answering my question.

I've seen some advocates titling the sale deed as only a “SALE DEED” and few advocates titling the sale deed as an “ABSOLUTE SALE DEED”. 

What's the actual difference between both and please prescribe the correct title to be affixed to a registered Sale Deed.

									Dear Client,
A "Sale Deed" and an "Absolute Sale Deed" are related legal documents used in property transactions, but they have distinct differences:

Sale Deed:
A Sale Deed is a legal document used to transfer the ownership of a property from the seller (transferor) to the buyer (transferee).
It is a standard document in property transactions and is used to establish that the seller has conveyed all rights, title, and interest in the property to the buyer.
A Sale Deed typically includes details such as the property description, sale price, names and details of the parties involved, and any conditions or covenants related to the sale.
It is a fundamental document for property transactions and serves as evidence of the transfer of property ownership.

Absolute Sale Deed:
An Absolute Sale Deed is essentially the same as a Sale Deed, with the term "absolute" emphasizing the completeness and finality of the property transfer.
It implies that there are no conditions, encumbrances, or restrictions on the property being transferred. In other words, the property is being transferred without any reservations, limitations, or rights retained by the seller.
An Absolute Sale Deed is used to confirm that the seller has an unencumbered and undisputed right to sell the property and that the buyer is receiving clear and absolute ownership.
The term "absolute" is often used to reassure the buyer that there are no hidden liabilities or claims on the property.

In summary, while both a Sale Deed and an Absolute Sale Deed serve the purpose of transferring property ownership, the latter emphasizes the absence of any conditions, encumbrances, or limitations on the property being conveyed. The use of "absolute" in the deed underscores the completeness and finality of the property transfer, providing additional assurance to the buyer regarding the property's title and ownership.

Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881, deals with the offense of dishonor of a cheque for insufficiency of funds or if it exceeds the amount arranged to be paid by the drawer's account. In cases related to dishonored cheques, several factors and legal principles come into play:

Cheque Amount: In the scenario you've described, the cheque was dishonored for Rs. 25 lakh. This suggests that the cheque amount exceeded the funds available in the drawer's account.

However, this condition may not necessarily absolve the drawer of the responsibility for the cheque's dishonor if it exceeds the available funds.

Crossed Cheque: Whether the cheque was crossed or not may also be relevant. Crossed cheques are meant to be paid into a bank account and not encashed over the counter. The presence or absence of a crossing may impact the legal considerations.

Questioning Witnesses: In a legal case related to a dishonored cheque, both the prosecution and the defense may present witnesses and evidence to support their respective arguments. The court will consider all the evidence, including the testimony of witnesses, documents, and the applicable laws.

If you are separated from your husband but not yet divorced, he will still have a legal right over the property that you jointly own, including the house that your sister has bought and made you a co-owner of. In the event of your demise, your husband will still have a legal right over your share of the property. This is because the law does not recognize common law marriage in India. There are other pieces of evidence that you may be able to produce, such as witness testimony or documentary evidence.

									In many legal systems, the admissibility of electronic evidence, including mobile chats and photographs, can be subject to specific rules and procedures. The process of admitting electronic evidence typically involves ensuring its authenticity and integrity.

Here are a few points to consider:

    Section 65B of the Indian Evidence Act: In India, Section 65B of the Indian Evidence Act relates to the admissibility of electronic records. It outlines the conditions under which electronic evidence, such as mobile chats and photographs, can be admitted in court. According to this section, electronic evidence must be accompanied by a certificate issued by a person in charge of the relevant device, confirming the accuracy of the contents. This certificate is commonly referred to as the "65B certificate."

    Admissibility of Mobile Handsets: If your advocate is preparing an application to produce the mobile handsets as evidence, it's likely that they are seeking to establish the authenticity of the mobile chats and photographs through these handsets. The court may consider the handsets as physical evidence that could potentially help establish the authenticity of the electronic records.

    Relevance and Authenticity: To strengthen your case, it's important to establish the relevance and authenticity of the evidence you're presenting. If the mobile chats and photographs are crucial to your case, you might need to provide evidence that demonstrates their relevance to the matter at hand and their authenticity.

    Expert Testimony: In some cases, expert testimony may be required to establish the authenticity and accuracy of electronic evidence, including mobile chats and photographs. This could involve a forensic expert who can verify the integrity of the data and explain its authenticity to the court.

data:
Sir /Madam

Both husband and wife belong to same district. 
But now, for work purpose both stay in Bangalore but wife has been deserted by husband.
She stays with her cousins in Bangalore. Husband stays in Bangalore but do not know the correct address. He also changed his company. 
She tried several ways to get the address but was not able to get it. 
Wife wanted to file crpc 125 in Bangalore for maintenance.. can she send notice to the native address of husband where his Parents is residing. Can his parents deny taking the notice .
It's been more then 1year 5 months I have been staying with my cousins. 
									
									 
									
									Dear Client,
Yes, the wife can send the legal notice to the husband's native address where his parents are residing. The parents are legally bound to accept the notice and inform the husband about it. In your case, since you do not know the correct address of your husband, you can send the legal notice to his native address where his parents are residing. The parents are legally bound to accept the notice and inform the husband about it.

So don't be scared the police will look into this and you may do what ever police said to do like blocking the number and providing them the number etc. You may ignore the phone call as it is a scam, if that would really happened police could not asked for bribe. So it is purely an scam, you may ignore the call and block it.
Thank you. 										
									 
									
									Based on the information you provided, it is highly likely that you were targeted by a scam call. There are several reasons to believe this:

Unverified Caller: The person claimed to be an S.H.O. (Station House Officer) from a specific Delhi police station, but you did not have a way to verify their identity.

Unusual and Unsubstantiated Claims: The story about a murder case, call records, chats, and banking transactions related to explicit content all sound highly unusual and lack credibility.

Request for Money: The scammer requested money to "close the case," which is a common tactic in extortion scams.

No Official Communication: In genuine legal matters, law enforcement would not typically contact someone about a serious case over the phone and request payment to resolve it. Official communication is usually done through formal notices or in-person visits.

No Personal Involvement: You mentioned that you have never been to Delhi, which would make it highly unlikely that you would be involved in a murder case in that city.

It's good that you did not send any money and informed your local police about the incident. Scammers often use fear and intimidation to try to extort money from their victims.

In cases like this, it's essential to take the following steps:

Do not engage with the scammer: Avoid further communication with the caller. Block their number if possible.

Report the incident: Report the scam to your local police or law enforcement agency. They may provide guidance on how to proceed.

Keep records: If you have any information about the call, such as the phone number, date, and time of the call, keep a record of it. This information may be useful for authorities.

Stay cautious: Be cautious of unsolicited calls or messages and be wary of sharing personal or financial information with unknown callers.

Based on the details you provided, it is highly unlikely that a genuine case has been filed against you in this manner. Scammers often use fear tactics to exploit individuals, so it's essential to remain vigilant and take appropriate steps to protect yourself from such scams.

headline: Review and Appeal in Consumer protection act
data:
Consumer protection act, 2019

Section 40 - Review by District Commission in certain cases
Section 41 - Appeal against order of District Commission

Can a complainant avail any one remedy only ( Section 40 - Review, OR Section 41 - Appeal to State Commission ) against an order passed by District Commission ?

Means, if Review is filed in District Commission under section 40, does it forfeit right to file Appeal under section 41 later, in the same issue ?

An Advocate has advised that only one remedy could be availed - either review in District Commission, OR appeal in State Commission. If any one remedy is availed, other would be forfeit.



									
									 
									
									Dear Client,
Yes, you are right. A complainant can avail only one remedy against an order passed by the District Commission. Section 40 of the Consumer Protection Act, 2019 provides for a review of an order passed by the District Commission, while Section 41 provides for an appeal against an order passed by the District Commission.
Thank you.

headline: Wrongful application of Sarfeisi Act-2002
data:
When there is a wrong application of Sec 13(4) against Symbolic possession Surfeisi Act 2002 avoiding reply under sec 13(2) notification & mandatory reply under sec 13 (3A), why should a borrower knock the door of DRT under Sec 17. A wrongful notification of lender under sec 13(4),should not entitled borrower to lodge grievances in DRT. A CS should suffice for stay or any such preventive action.									
									 
									
									Dear Client,
The Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest Act, 2002 (SARFAESI Act) is a law that provides for the speedy recovery of debts by financial institutions. Section 13(4) of the SARFAESI Act allows a secured creditor to take possession of the secured assets of the borrower if the borrower defaults on the loan repayment. In this case, the borrower can challenge the action of the secured creditor in the DRT. The DRT may order the secured creditor to return the secured assets to the borrower or may take other appropriate action. The borrower does not need to file a civil suit in order to challenge the action of the secured creditor. They can directly file a case in the DRT.
Thank you.

headline: House property share
data:
My father had a own house. My father had not made any legal will. My father had two male children, one my elder brother and another one is me. Now, my father, mother and my elder brother had expired. My brother had not made any legal will. My elder brother had married and no children. My father's house is in my father's name. The wife of my brother is still alive.

Question : Whether my brother's wife has power to make legal will ?									
									 
									
									Since your brother's wife is now one of legal heir and have equal rights in the property, she can will for her share in the property 										
									 
									
									SHE HAS SAME RIGHT WHAT YOUR BROTHER WOULD HAVE GOT .CLICK 										
									 
									
									Dear Client,
No, your brother's wife does not have the power to make a legal will on behalf of your brother. Only your brother could have made a legal will, and since he did not, the property will be inherited by his legal heirs. In India, the legal heirs of a person are determined by the Hindu Succession Act, 1956. Under the Act, the legal heirs of a Hindu male who dies intestate (without a will) are his wife, children, parents, and siblings. In your case, since your brother died without any children, his wife will be one of his legal heirs.  She will not have the power to make a legal will on his behalf. The property will be inherited by the remaining legal heirs, which in this case are you and your parents.
Thank you.										
									 
									
									No. She does not have rights on the property.

										
									 
									
									Property is required to be partitioned first. The share of brother shall devolve to his wife and children and they have every right to claim partition and to bequeath his portion. 										
									 
									
									No, your brother's wife does not have the power to make a legal will on behalf of your brother.
Under the Indian Succession Act, 1925, a person who dies without a will is said to have died intestate. In the case of an intestate succession, the property of the deceased person is distributed among his/her legal heirs in accordance with the law.
The legal heirs of your brother are you and your brother's wife. Since your brother had no children, his wife is a Class I heir. This means that she is entitled to an equal share of your brother's property, along with you.
Your brother's wife cannot make a legal will on behalf of your brother because she is not his legal heir. Only a legal heir can make a legal will on behalf of a deceased person.
However, your brother's wife can make a will of her own property. If she dies without a will, her property will be distributed among her legal heirs in accordance with the law.

									Dear Client,
Yes, you as the complainant can appoint a Senior Counsel for the case. The Bombay High Court rules do not specifically prohibit a complainant from appointing a Senior Counsel. In fact, the court has held that a complainant has the right to appoint a lawyer of his/her choice.
Thank you.

									In India, a Senior Counsel (often referred to as a Senior Advocate) is typically a designated senior lawyer with special privileges and standing in courts. Their roles are somewhat different from that of an Advocate on Record (AOR) or a briefing lawyer.

You, as a litigant, certainly have the right to appoint a Senior Counsel for your case. However, the usual practice is for your advocate or briefing lawyer to consult with you and then engage the Senior Counsel on your behalf. This is because your advocate is more likely to be familiar with the intricacies of the case, the specific legal points that need to be argued, and which Senior Counsel might be best suited for the particular nature of the case.

Here are a few things to consider:

Engagement Process: While you can express a desire or preference for a particular Senior Counsel, the actual engagement process, including discussions about availability, fees, and briefing, is typically done through your advocate.

Briefing Session: Once a Senior Counsel is engaged, there's usually a 'briefing session' where your advocate explains the case details to the Senior Counsel. You might be asked to attend this session, especially if there are complex facts or nuances that need to be explained.

Multiple Lawyers: It's not uncommon for litigants to have multiple lawyers represent them in a single matter. You might have an Advocate on Record, a briefing lawyer, and one or more Senior Counsels for various hearings.

Cost Consideration: Engaging a Senior Counsel can be expensive, so you should be clear about the financial implications.

Direct Engagement: In some exceptional circumstances, litigants might engage a Senior Counsel directly without going through an advocate. However, this is not the usual practice, and it's advisable to have an advocate to manage the procedural aspects of the case.

In any event, it's crucial to maintain open communication with your advocate. If you wish to engage a Senior Counsel, discuss this with your advocate to ensure a coordinated and effective legal strategy. Remember, the ultimate aim is to present your case in the best possible manner, and teamwork between your advocate and the Senior Counsel is paramount for this.

However, as always, the exact practices and procedures can vary based on jurisdictional nuances and specific circumstances. It's advisable to consult with your advocate and possibly seek a second opinion if you're unsure about the way forward.

									If you have lost the original survey "pavti" (receipt or document) from the year 2000 but have a photocopy, you may need to follow certain procedures to obtain a certified duplicate or to ensure the validity of your claims based on the document. Here's a general approach you might consider:

Visit the Concerned Office: Depending on where you obtained the original "pavti" or the type of survey document it is, you should visit the concerned government office. This might be the local land records office, tehsil office, or any other relevant authority.

File an Application: Submit a written application explaining the loss of the original document and request a certified copy of the same. Attach the photocopy you have, if necessary. Some offices may have specific application forms for this purpose.

FIR (First Information Report): In some cases, especially if the document is critical, you might be advised to file an FIR or a non-cognizable report (NCR) at the local police station stating the loss of the original document. This step helps in two ways: it protects you if the lost document is misused, and it provides a formal record that you reported the loss.

Newspaper Advertisement: Some jurisdictions or offices might require you to publish an advertisement in a local newspaper about the loss of the document. This public notice serves as a warning to others that the original document is lost and that you possess only a copy.

Affidavit: You might also need to get an affidavit notarized stating the loss of the original document and that you will be using the photocopy for all official purposes. The affidavit serves as a legal statement of the facts and can be used in the future, if required, to support your claim.

Fees: There might be nominal fees associated with obtaining a certified copy or completing other related procedures.

Keep All Records: Once you've completed these processes, ensure you safely store all the related documents, including the application, FIR or NCR, newspaper advertisement, and affidavit. This will be useful for future references.

Consult With an Expert: It's always beneficial to consult with a legal expert or someone familiar with land records in your area to guide you through the process.

It's essential to act promptly when you realize you've lost such a document to prevent potential misuse and to ensure you have all necessary records in place.
