									The processes and timelines in the courts can vary based on various factors, such as the workload of the court, the specifics of the case, and other administrative elements. However, I can give you a general overview of the process:

Issuance and Service of Summons: After filing your case, the court will issue a summons to the respondent (in this case, your tenant). The court usually directs the process server or bailiff to serve the summons to the respondent. In the context of the Small Causes Court in Mumbai:

Typically, the summons could be served within a few days to a couple of weeks after the case is filed, but the exact timeline can vary. By the time of the next hearing, the court will expect the summons to have been served unless there are exceptional circumstances.
Appearance of the Respondent: Once the summons is served, the respondent is expected to appear on the given date of hearing, either personally or through an advocate.

Filing of Written Statement: If the respondent disputes your claims, they would be given a specific time to file their written statement, which is essentially their defense against your claims.

Framing of Issues: Based on your suit and the respondent's written statement, the court will frame issues that need to be adjudicated. These issues are essentially points of contention or questions that need to be answered.

Evidence Stage: Both parties will be given an opportunity to present evidence to support their claims or defenses. This evidence could be in the form of documents, witness testimonies, or any other relevant material.

Arguments: After the evidence has been presented, both sides will have the opportunity to make their arguments based on the evidence and the law.

Judgment: After considering the evidence and arguments presented by both sides, the court will deliver its judgment.

It's important to note that the above is a broad overview, and the exact procedure can vary. Cases under the Maharashtra Rent Control Act can involve specific nuances, especially considering the nature of the sections you mentioned (which deal with aspects like unlawful subletting, repairs, and nuisance).

To navigate this process effectively:

Hire a good advocate (if you haven't already) who is familiar with the Maharashtra Rent Control Act and the workings of the Small Causes Court in Bandra.
Stay updated: Ensure you are in regular communication with your advocate, ask about the status of the summons and other procedural matters.
Prepare your evidence and witnesses in advance, so you're ready when the evidence stage comes.
Lastly, always refer to the specific advice of your advocate since they'll have the most accurate and detailed understanding of your case's proceedings.

headline: Applicability of Which law Sunni Muslim law or Indian Succession Act.
data:
A Sunni Muslim Widow married to Christian Man, She has no parents, no sibling, no children and no Husband. has made a WILL of her estate in favor of Trust made in her name. What would be challenges of Will. and which law will be applicable to her Sunni Muslim inheritance law or Indian Succession Act. ?

Advocate, A.P.Loganathan, Madras High Court
Please click LIKE for encouraging/appreciating me
For more clarification contact me, getting details from path legal or Google site
										
									 
									
									Dear Client,
In India, the law that governs wills is the Indian Succession Act, 1925. This law applies to all citizens of India, regardless of their religion. The Indian Succession Act does not specifically address the issue of a Muslim widow making a will in favor of a trust. The Act does provide that a will can be made in favor of any person or entity. The will may be Challenged as:
The will is not valid because it was not made in accordance with the Muslim Personal Law.
The will is not valid because it is not in the best interests of the widow's heirs.
Thank you.										
									 
									
									When a Sunni Muslim woman marries a Christian man in India, several legal complexities arise, especially in matters related to succession and inheritance.

Personal Laws vs. Indian Succession Act: Sunni Muslims in India are generally governed by their personal laws when it comes to matters of inheritance. However, when a Muslim woman marries a non-Muslim, there are complications:

Under the Muslim Personal Law, the marriage between a Sunni Muslim woman and a Christian man would be considered void unless the man converts to Islam before the marriage.
If the marriage is considered void, then her inheritance would typically be governed by Sunni Muslim inheritance law.
However, if she has made a will, the situation changes. The will of a Muslim who is not governed by the Shariat (i.e., when the woman is married to a non-Muslim and opts out of the Muslim Personal Law) can be governed by the Indian Succession Act.
Validity of the Will: For the will to be valid:

It must be signed by the testator (the person making the will).
The testator must be of sound mind at the time of making the will.
The will should be attested by at least two witnesses.
The will should not have been made under coercion or undue influence.
Challenges to the Will:

Validity of the Marriage: Since interfaith marriages without a formal conversion or without getting married under the Special Marriage Act can be contested in India, there's potential that the marriage's validity may be challenged, impacting the will indirectly.
Coercion or Undue Influence: If any party alleges that the will was made under coercion or undue influence, it can be challenged in court.
Questions of Law: There might be questions raised about which law applies: the Indian Succession Act or Muslim Personal Law. The fact that she has no Muslim legal heirs (like children or parents) might complicate this further.
Rights of the Trust: The terms and conditions governing the trust and its beneficiaries will also be examined to ensure that they are in line with legal standards.
Recommendations:

Legal Consultation: Given the complexities, it is crucial to consult with a lawyer experienced in both personal laws and the Indian Succession Act. They can guide on the potential challenges and ways to address them.
Clear Will Drafting: Ensure that the will is drafted clearly, detailing all assets and rights of the beneficiaries. The clearer and more specific the will, the fewer challenges it's likely to face.
Evidence of Sound Mind: Any documentation or proof that showcases that the will was made without coercion and by a person of sound mind can be beneficial.
In summary, while the will's creator has the right to bequeath her property as she sees fit, given the complexities involved in interfaith marriages and the coexistence of personal laws with the Indian Succession Act, it's vital to be prepared for potential challenges. A consultation with a legal expert in this area is highly recommended.

headline: Family civil suit section C or D under family matter
data:
Kharghar, raigad civi suit/ senior division family matter which jurisdiction come ? Whare case will file panvel court or alibag family court? 									
									 
									
									sir here it is not mention as where the incident took place for what the case is to be filed . as the case will be filed at the place of the accident or the incident took place . 										
									 
									
									Dear Client,
The jurisdiction of a court depends on the location of the incident took place or the parties involved in the case. In your matter if the incident has taken place in Kharghar, Raigad. So the case should be filed in the Raigad District Court, which has jurisdiction over all civil and family matters in the district. The Alibag bench also has jurisdiction over Kharghar, so you can file your case there as well.
Thank you.										
									 
									
									In Maharashtra, jurisdiction for civil suits is determined based on the subject matter and the territorial jurisdiction.

Territorial Jurisdiction:

Kharghar is located in the Raigad district of Maharashtra. Typically, the territorial jurisdiction for a matter arising in Kharghar would be the courts situated within the district.
Panvel Court: Panvel has its court, and given that Kharghar falls under Panvel Taluka, it is likely that the Panvel court would have jurisdiction for most civil matters arising in Kharghar.
Alibag Family Court: Alibag is the district headquarters for Raigad. If there is a specialized family court in Alibag, and if the matter pertains specifically to family disputes that fall under the purview of the Family Courts Act, then it might be more appropriate to approach the Alibag Family Court.
Nature of the Suit:

Civil Suit: If it's a general civil suit, it would likely be appropriate for the Panvel court.
Family Matter: Matters like matrimonial disputes, maintenance, child custody, etc., that fall under the Family Courts Act, are typically taken up by the Family Court. If Alibag has a specialized family court, then such matters might be directed there, even if they arise in Kharghar.
Recommendation:

Before filing any case, it's essential to consult with a local lawyer who is familiar with the courts in Raigad district. They can guide you on the specific court that would have jurisdiction for your matter.
Sometimes, even if a particular court has jurisdiction, parties might mutually agree to have their dispute adjudicated in another court. However, this would depend on the nature of the dispute and the willingness of both parties.
Always ensure that you're filing in the correct court to prevent any procedural issues or delays that might arise from jurisdictional challenges.

Section 420 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860, deals with fraud. The section states that whoever cheats and thereby dishonestly induces the other person to deliver any property to him or to make any payment to him or to do or omit to do anything which he would not do or omit to do, if he does not believe the deception, is said to commit fraud.

									What's Cybercrime? 
Cybercrime typically involves unauthorized access to confidential or private information that is stored online, on computers, or on internet databases. This can include information such as:
•	Names and contact info
•	Date of Birth
•	Social Security numbers
•	Bank account information
•	Credit card and credit info
•	Trade secrets
•	Trademark and copyright info
Cybercrime can be accomplished through a number of ways, such as hacking, theft of passwords, fraud or misrepresentation, and other devices.
Are There Any Defenses to Cybercrime?
Although many cybercrime violations can involve serious legal penalties, there can also be some defenses to cybercrime. These may include:
•	Authorization – The person being charged with cyber crimes was actually authorized to access the information
•	Lack of knowledge – Many cyber crimes, such as internet fraud, require that the defendant knew what they were doing and intended to engage the victim in fraud. It may be a defense for instance if the person didn’t know that a certain form was fake, etc.
•	Coercion – It can sometimes be a defense if a person was forced to commit cyber crime under threat of harm or punishment to themselves or a loved one
What If I’m Facing Cybercrime Charges?
Many computer databases and internet devices have tracking mechanisms that record cyber activity. This can often help prove one’s innocence in a cyber crime case. These may include "time stamps" of when a person logged into an account; they can also tell from which location certain transactions occurred, and who authorized them. So, it may be helpful to obtain this type of information when facing cybercrime charges.
Some of these methods are technically advanced and may require the assistance of a trained IT professional and/or the assistance of a lawyer.
Do I Need a Lawyer for Help with Cybercrime Defenses?
Cyber crime can sometimes be a vague area of law since many of these crimes are quite new. You may wish to hire a criminal lawyer if you need assistance with a defense case. Your attorney can help locate and gather evidence that might help in proving your innocence. Also, if you need more information or research on legal issues, your lawyer can provide you with up-to-date legal info on cyber crime law

data:

I complete it and they said it's not 90% accuracy and had to pay a fine of 7670 rupees and said I have to work for another 2 weeks total of 1200 forums I said I could not do it the gave me a legal case and said I have to appear in the court for contract breach.What should I do ?

Is online data entry jobs are fake?
it is totally scam people don't fall in to it they are not going to pay you anything they don't have proper company details or contact details you can not contact them for any issue after doing 5000rs work they will not pay..

Fake Data Entry Jobs To Beware Of
How does this fake data entry jobs racket operate?
Two companies, Oval Solution and Unitec Solution, get details of candidates from their online job websites profiles, such as Quikr. They offer the candidates to work from home opportunity. In Jasveer’s case, he was asked to write 120 pages by Unitec and type 10,000 captchas by Oval. Some employers even ask candidates to watch videos on YouTube. This work includes increasing video views. Jasveer was promised a remuneration of Rs 30,000 by Oval and Rs 25,200 by Unitec. Upon condition that he would complete his task within 12 days and with a 90% accuracy.
The scammers seem to be a full team of engineers, business developers and lawyers. They target people who have their resumes uploaded on job portals and are looking for work. They also lure people in by sending out mass messages. These messages often sound too good to be true. The content is usually to earn a big amount within a few days by working from home.
The scamming techniques
But the problem begins when firstly the task load seems difficult to complete within the allotted time period. Secondly, employers always take out maximum errors in the candidate’s work. Thus, making it extremely difficult to complete one’s task successfully. Which also happened in the case of Jasveer. Thirdly, the employers charge Rs 10,000 for utility and maintenance from the candidate. Though they promise to refund this amount in the succeeding month. Fourthly, the employers ask the candidate for their photo and digital signature. They then illegally use it on a contract of work between the employer and the candidate. Although, everything written on the contract was never communicated to the candidate in the first place. So candidates are left in the dark for what they are agreeing to.
For instance, in Jasveer’s case, the contract included that he would have to pay the utility charges monthly. It also said that if he was unable to complete his task within the given period, then he would be subjected to a penalty of Rs 10,000 by the employer for their loss. Inability to pay the penalty would result in a court case. Furthermore, withdrawing the court case would need a separate payment.
To scare the candidate further, they put a breach of contact on them under Section 73, 74 and 75 of the Indian Contract Act. The fake data entry jobs also call the candidates from pretending lawyers who ask them for money to withdraw their court case. The candidates would receive a no-objection certificate upon the payment. Then they will be free to go.
Later, the employers reveal that the contract was actually for 11 months. So the candidate either has to work for the full term or pay the utility charges for the full term. In short, they do not let the candidate escape and keep harassing him for more money, as was the case with Jasveer.
The loopholes in the ongoing fake data entry jobs scam
Upon consulting with Advocate Naman Mohnot on this situation, we got a clear idea of how the employers were trying to scam naive candidates. The two companies, Oval Solutions and Unitec Solutions, were harassing people with an Intent to Cheat. This means that the employer always wanted the candidate to fail and loot money from them maliciously. Thus, it could lead to a case of 420 on the employer. Intent to cheat was can verified due to the following reasons:
•	The employer never asks the candidate for his ITR or bank records to check their paying capacity in the case of a penalty.
•	An employer would never hire any candidate without interviewing them or any proof of their working capability. In Jasveer’s case, he was never interviewed. He was just given the job and promised a fixed amount.
•	Online freelance websites never ask for money from candidates for incomplete tasks.
•	A company is eligible to ask for a refund from the candidate only when they invest in his training. Plus the candidate needs to have a signed bond with the company. But claiming for compensation without any investment on the candidate is a fraud.
•	A valid agreement or contract has to have the written signature of both parties. In Jasveer’s case, it was just an image of his signature. Additionally, two witnesses signatures are also compulsory on the agreement. This was lacking in Jasveer’s case too.
•	There is also no notarization of the agreement or contract.
•	It is also illegal to put multiple one-sided clauses in an agreement. Even if the other party signs the agreement, they are not held to fulfilling so many one-sided clauses.
•	The employers also did not allow Jasveer additional days to check his work, even when his submission was before the due date. Thus the time duration given was invalid.
•	There are also multiple and irrelevant calls from the company to scare candidates. There is no continuity in what they say either.
•	The actual terms of the agreement are hidden on call before the candidate signs it, that too without his consent.
History of these fake data entry jobs companies
A quick Google search for Oval Solutions and Unitec Solutions leads one to the Consumer Complaints Forum. Here, multiple sources claim the scam they are facing from these fake data entry jobs. These fake data entry jobs firms are eligible to be sued under Sections 406 and 420 of the IPC. Filing an FIR against these companies is the ultimate answer.

Fake Data Entry Jobs To Beware Of
How does this fake data entry jobs racket operate?
Two companies, Oval Solution and Unitec Solution, get details of candidates from their online job websites profiles, such as Quikr. They offer the candidates to work from home opportunity. In Jasveer’s case, he was asked to write 120 pages by Unitec and type 10,000 captchas by Oval. Some employers even ask candidates to watch videos on YouTube. This work includes increasing video views. Jasveer was promised a remuneration of Rs 30,000 by Oval and Rs 25,200 by Unitec. Upon condition that he would complete his task within 12 days and with a 90% accuracy.
The scammers seem to be a full team of engineers, business developers and lawyers. They target people who have their resumes uploaded on job portals and are looking for work. They also lure people in by sending out mass messages. These messages often sound too good to be true. The content is usually to earn a big amount within a few days by working from home.
The scamming techniques
But the problem begins when firstly the task load seems difficult to complete within the allotted time period. Secondly, employers always take out maximum errors in the candidate’s work. Thus, making it extremely difficult to complete one’s task successfully. Which also happened in the case of Jasveer. Thirdly, the employers charge Rs 10,000 for utility and maintenance from the candidate. Though they promise to refund this amount in the succeeding month. Fourthly, the employers ask the candidate for their photo and digital signature. They then illegally use it on a contract of work between the employer and the candidate. Although, everything written on the contract was never communicated to the candidate in the first place. So candidates are left in the dark for what they are agreeing to.
For instance, in Jasveer’s case, the contract included that he would have to pay the utility charges monthly. It also said that if he was unable to complete his task within the given period, then he would be subjected to a penalty of Rs 10,000 by the employer for their loss. Inability to pay the penalty would result in a court case. Furthermore, withdrawing the court case would need a separate payment.
To scare the candidate further, they put a breach of contact on them under Section 73, 74 and 75 of the Indian Contract Act. The fake data entry jobs also call the candidates from pretending lawyers who ask them for money to withdraw their court case. The candidates would receive a no-objection certificate upon the payment. Then they will be free to go.
Later, the employers reveal that the contract was actually for 11 months. So the candidate either has to work for the full term or pay the utility charges for the full term. In short, they do not let the candidate escape and keep harassing him for more money, as was the case with Jasveer.
The loopholes in the ongoing fake data entry jobs scam
Upon consulting with Advocate Naman Mohnot on this situation, we got a clear idea of how the employers were trying to scam naive candidates. The two companies, Oval Solutions and Unitec Solutions, were harassing people with an Intent to Cheat. This means that the employer always wanted the candidate to fail and loot money from them maliciously. Thus, it could lead to a case of 420 on the employer. Intent to cheat was can verified due to the following reasons:
•	The employer never asks the candidate for his ITR or bank records to check their paying capacity in the case of a penalty.
•	An employer would never hire any candidate without interviewing them or any proof of their working capability. In Jasveer’s case, he was never interviewed. He was just given the job and promised a fixed amount.
•	Online freelance websites never ask for money from candidates for incomplete tasks.
•	A company is eligible to ask for a refund from the candidate only when they invest in his training. Plus the candidate needs to have a signed bond with the company. But claiming for compensation without any investment on the candidate is a fraud.
•	A valid agreement or contract has to have the written signature of both parties. In Jasveer’s case, it was just an image of his signature. Additionally, two witnesses signatures are also compulsory on the agreement. This was lacking in Jasveer’s case too.
•	There is also no notarization of the agreement or contract.
•	It is also illegal to put multiple one-sided clauses in an agreement. Even if the other party signs the agreement, they are not held to fulfilling so many one-sided clauses.
•	The employers also did not allow Jasveer additional days to check his work, even when his submission was before the due date. Thus the time duration given was invalid.
•	There are also multiple and irrelevant calls from the company to scare candidates. There is no continuity in what they say either.
•	The actual terms of the agreement are hidden on call before the candidate signs it, that too without his consent.
History of these fake data entry jobs companies
A quick Google search for Oval Solutions and Unitec Solutions leads one to the Consumer Complaints Forum. Here, multiple sources claim the scam they are facing from these fake data entry jobs. These fake data entry jobs firms are eligible to be sued under Sections 406 and 420 of the IPC. Filing an FIR against these companies is the ultimate answer.
*******

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through this. It sounds like you've been the victim of a scam. You can send them a letter or email requesting a refund, explaining that you were misled into paying for services that you didn't receive. The Consumer Protection Act, 2019, gives consumers the right to file a complaint against any company that has violated their rights. You can find more information about how to file a complaint on the NCDRC website. The Consumer Protection Act, 2019, prohibits unfair trade practices, such as misleading or deceptive advertising. 
Thank you.

									Acquiring Indian citizenship for a Nepalese citizen involves a legal process and meeting specific criteria. Given the friendly relationship between India and Nepal, many Nepalese nationals live and work in India under the framework of the India-Nepal Treaty of Peace and Friendship of 1950. However, living in India does not automatically grant one Indian citizenship.

To apply for Indian citizenship, here are the general steps and criteria:

Eligibility: As a foreign national, you can apply for Indian citizenship by Naturalization if you have resided in India during the last 12 months and for 11 out of the 14 years before the 12 months.

Application: You need to apply to the Ministry of Home Affairs on Form XII, as provided in the Third Schedule to the Citizenship Rules, 2009.

Documentation:

Proof of residence in India for the qualifying period.
A good character certificate.
Knowledge of any language in the Eighth Schedule to the Constitution.
Renunciation of your Nepalese citizenship because India does not allow dual citizenship.
Oath of Allegiance: Once your application is approved, you need to take an Oath of Allegiance as a final step.

Special Considerations for Nepalese Nationals:

While the India-Nepal Treaty allows Nepalese citizens to reside and work in India without requiring a visa, this does not equate to citizenship. Therefore, the process of naturalization remains the primary route.
Remember that acquiring Indian citizenship would mean giving up Nepalese citizenship, as neither country recognizes dual citizenship.
Consultation: Always consult with an immigration lawyer in India for detailed guidance tailored to your specific situation. They can guide you through the process, assist with documentation, and help ensure that you meet all requirements.

Further Scrutiny: Applications for citizenship are carefully scrutinized, and it might be beneficial to have an advocate or a legal expert help you with the process.

Given the importance and complexity of such a decision and process, ensure you have all the facts, implications, and support you need before proceeding.

									based on the sequence of legal actions you've described, there are a few important points to note:

Res Judicata Principle: The principle of "res judicata" prevents the same parties from litigating on the same issue more than once. Since the Supreme Court, which is the highest court in the country, has already passed judgment on your matter (including the review and curative petitions), it may be challenging to bring the same cause of action before the court again.

Special Leave Petition (SLP): An SLP in the Supreme Court is generally used to appeal against judgments from lower courts or tribunals. Given that you've already gone to the Supreme Court and had subsequent petitions dismissed, it would be critical to consult with legal counsel on the feasibility and rationale for filing an SLP.

NCDRC Complaint: Filing a complaint for a third time under fresh and continued cause of action would require clear, distinct, and new grounds that haven't been presented before. Even then, the NCDRC might view the repeated petitions with caution, especially if there's significant overlap with prior complaints.

Appointment of Doctor's Panel: The courts have discretionary powers regarding the appointment of expert panels or committees. While you can request this, it's not guaranteed. Courts might rely on available evidence and arguments presented before them.

New Legal Avenues: If there are genuinely new grounds or new evidence that wasn't available or considered in previous complaints, you might consider discussing with your legal counsel about how best to approach this. It might provide a new avenue for legal action.

Legal Advice: Given the complexity of your case and the number of legal actions you've already undertaken, it's crucial to consult with a seasoned legal practitioner familiar with medical negligence cases in India. 									Dear Client,
If the entry is not available with the gramme Panchayat office, you can file a petition under section 13(3) of the Registration of Birth and Death Act with the help of a lawyer in a court in your city.
There is a legal presumption that an adult man and woman are married after they have lived together for a significant amount of time as husband and wife. There is no need for a marriage certificate, invitation card, or wedding photos. The status of a second wife is only in doubt if the wife is residing with the husband. 
In India, Marriages can be registered either under the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 or under the Special Marriage Act, 1954. For both types of marriages, a marriage certificate is legitimate proof that a couple is married.

Thank You										
									 
									
									Testimonial evidence: This includes the testimony of witnesses who can testify that the marriage took place. This could include close friends or relatives of the couple, or anyone else who was present at the wedding.
Documentary evidence: This could include any documents related to the marriage, such as a marriage certificate, a wedding invitation, or a photograph of the wedding.
Circumstantial evidence: This could include evidence that suggests that the marriage was valid, such as the fact that the couple lived together as husband and wife and had children together.
In your case, since there is no record of the death of the first wife or the marriage registration of the second wife, it will be more difficult to prove the legality of the marriage. However, it is still possible to do so by gathering the necessary evidence.
You should consult with me 

Adv. Sarika Khude
Rajgurunagar Pune										
									 
									
									Establishing the legality of a marriage, especially when it happened a long time ago and lacks direct documentation, can be challenging. Here are some general steps and methods that might be considered to try and establish the legality of the marriage in the context of a civil suit in India:

Personal Testimonies: Witnesses who were present during the marriage can provide testimony confirming the occurrence of the marriage. These could be friends, relatives, or neighbors who were present during the marriage ceremonies.

Photographs: Any photographs from the wedding ceremony could serve as circumstantial evidence of the marriage.

Rituals and Customs: Explaining the rituals and customs that were followed during the marriage and having witnesses testify about them can be useful, especially in the context of Hindu marriage, which has certain ceremonies like 'Saptapadi' (seven steps) which are considered crucial for the marriage.

Presence of a Priest: If a priest officiated the marriage and he is still alive, his testimony can be pivotal. If not, records or any other evidence of his involvement could help.

Subsequent Conduct: Evidence of the couple living together as husband and wife, having children, attending family or public events together, or any other social acknowledgment of their status as a married couple can serve as circumstantial evidence.

Financial and Property Records: Any joint property or financial transactions, bank accounts, or investments can serve as evidence of a marital relationship.

Invitation Cards: If there were any invitation cards for the marriage, they could serve as evidence.

Affidavits: In the absence of direct evidence, affidavits from close relatives or friends attesting to the fact of marriage can be presented.

Children's Birth Certificates: If the couple had children, their birth certificates showing the names of both the husband and wife can be an indirect proof of their marriage.

Any Other Indirect Evidence: Any letters, documents, or communications between the couple or with others which indicate their status as husband and wife can be valuable.

Lack of Opposition: If no one contested or objected to the marriage at the time, that itself might be used as circumstantial evidence of its validity.

Remember, given that this is a legal issue pertaining to a partition suit and the legitimacy of a marriage, it's crucial to work closely with a legal professional in India who can provide guidance tailored to your specific circumstances. Only a qualified lawyer can give legal advice on how best to present the evidence in court and address any legal challenges that might arise.

									The SARFAESI Act, 2002 (Securitization and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest Act, 2002) is an Indian law that allows banks and other financial institutions to recover their non-performing assets (NPAs) without the intervention of the court.

As per the act:

Section 13(2): If a borrower defaults in repayment and the account is classified as a Non-Performing Asset (NPA), the secured creditor can issue a notice to the borrower asking them to discharge their liabilities within 60 days.

Section 13(3A): If the borrower raises any objection or places any representation against the notice issued under Section 13(2), the secured creditor should consider such representation or objection and send a reply to the borrower within 15 days.

The provision does suggest that the creditor should reply within 15 days. However, if courts have interpreted this time frame as non-mandatory, then the explicit mandatory period is not binding. But even so, the bank or financial institution must act in a reasonable timeframe. What is considered "reasonable" may vary and often depends on the facts and circumstances of each case.

Section 13(4): If the borrower fails to comply with the notice under Section 13(2), the creditor has the right to take possession of the assets, sell the assets, or take over the management of the business of the borrower.
There isn't a specific limitation period mentioned for lenders to reply before they proceed under Section 13(4). However, a lender should follow the procedures and timeframes laid down in the act to ensure that their actions are legally sound.

In any event, if you're dealing with an issue related to the SARFAESI Act, it would be prudent to consult with a legal professional in India who can provide detailed advice specific to your situation.

									Dear Client,

The Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest (SARFAESI) Act, 2002, is an Indian law that empowers banks and financial institutions to take possession of and sell assets pledged as collateral by borrowers in the event of default. Section 13(3A) of the SARFAESI Act pertains to the right of the borrower to appeal against the action taken by the secured creditor (bank or financial institution) under Section 13(4).

Section 13(3A) reads as follows:

"(3A) Any person (including borrower), aggrieved by any of the measures referred to in sub-section (4) of section 13 taken by the secured creditor or his authorised officer under this Act, may make an application along with such fee, as may be prescribed, to the Debts Recovery Tribunal having jurisdiction in the matter within forty-five days from the date on which such measures had been taken: Provided that different fees may be prescribed for making the application by the borrower and the person other than the borrower."

This section essentially grants the borrower the right to appeal against the actions taken by the secured creditor (usually a bank) under Section 13(4) of the SARFAESI Act. Section 13(4) deals with the measures that a secured creditor can take to recover their dues, including taking possession of the secured assets and selling them to recover the outstanding debt. If the borrower is aggrieved by such actions, they have the option to file an application with the Debts Recovery Tribunal (DRT) within forty-five days of the date on which the measures were taken. The appeal must be accompanied by the prescribed fee.

In the context of the Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Security Interest Act (SARFAESI Act) of 2002, the specific time frame within which a lender should reply to the representation of a borrower under Section 13(2) might not be explicitly defined in the Act itself.
However, the Act provides a mechanism for borrowers to make a representation against the measures taken by the lender under Section 13(2). The lender has the discretion to consider and reply to the borrower's representation. While there may not be a strict statutory time frame for the lender's response, it's generally advisable for lenders to reply within a reasonable time to ensure transparency and fair dealings.
If the lender fails to reply or the borrower is dissatisfied with the lender's response, the borrower can take recourse under Section 13(4) of the Act.

headline: How to save Captial Gains upon distribution of property
data:
HOW TO SAVE CAPITAL GAIN Our is a partnership firm with 3 partners. Recently we have decided to give away 2 properties to 2 partners(1 each) (all 3 alive) without any monetory consideration
(this is arising out of our internal family settlement as all 3 partners of the firm are real brothers)
Now we have been told that the Partnership property distribution will be subject to Captial gains. Can any one suggest how to do away with capital gains. We 3 partners are ready to explore retirement of partners reliqushment or also can explore for reducing capital/share of profits and also explore continuing the partnership firm.									
									 
									
									Long term capital gain tax can be saved by reinvesting in property or govt scheme and/or bonds.										
									 
									
									Dear Client,
Section 43 in The Indian Partnership Act, 1932. - Where the partnership is at will, the firm may be dissolved by any partner giving notice in writing to all the other partners of his intention to dissolve the firm. There are two ways by which you can get your share from the property.
Capital gains will be calculated on partnership firm. 

Section 43 of the partnership Act DISSOLUTION BY NOTICE OF PARTNERSHIP AT WILL. - Where the partnership is at will, the firm may be dissolved by any partner giving notice in writing to all the other partners of his intention to dissolve the firm.

Thank You
										
									 
									
									In India, the distribution of assets upon dissolution or otherwise from a partnership firm to its partners might result in capital gains tax implications. Here are some strategies you could consider to minimize or defer capital gains:

Retirement of Partners: Instead of dissolving the firm, consider the retirement of partners. When a partner retires and takes his share of the capital asset, it might be considered a mere distribution of his share in the partnership. However, the interpretation and tax implications may vary, and the tax treatment might be disputed by the tax authorities. You'll need to ensure that the transaction is structured correctly and in accordance with the partnership deed.

Revaluation of Assets: Revalue the assets of the partnership before the distribution. This might increase the book value of the asset, which could potentially reduce the capital gains that arise at the time of distribution.

Investing in Specific Bonds: If there's still a capital gain, you can consider investing the capital gains in specified bonds under Section 54EC of the Income Tax Act. These bonds have a lock-in period of 5 years and can help save taxes on the capital gains.

Investing in a New Property: Depending on the nature of the asset, if it's a real estate property, you might qualify for exemptions under Section 54 or Section 54F by reinvesting the capital gains in a new residential property.

Gift or Will: A more long-term approach might be to consider gifting the property or bequeathing it via a will, as gifts are generally not considered a 'transfer' for capital gains purposes. However, remember that there could be other implications like stamp duty.

Holding Period: If the properties are close to completing a holding period that will make them long-term capital assets (typically more than 24 months for property), it might be beneficial to wait. Long-term capital gains have more beneficial provisions for tax than short-term capital gains.

Transfer to an LLP: Another approach might be converting the partnership firm into an LLP (Limited Liability Partnership) and then distribute the assets. However, this has its own set of conditions and might not necessarily save you from capital gains tax, but could provide more flexibility.

Lastly, it's essential to work closely with a tax consultant or a chartered accountant familiar with such transactions. They will help structure the distribution in a manner most beneficial and compliant with the law. Given that tax laws and interpretations can be complex, professional guidance will ensure you take the right steps.

headline: Audio recording in CCTV camera
data:
My neighbour has installed a cctv camera with audio recording without my consent in the common passage area between our two flats. It records all conversations I have with my contacts.  I do not mind the camera capturing visuals.  But why record audio? And also without my consent.  What can I do?

									Inform police as intrusion of your privacy inbcriminal casr inform building secretary

									Dear Client,
Installing CCTV cameras is not illegal. It must not infringe on your neighbour's right to privacy if you install a CCTV camera in a shared space like a stairway and roof. You should consider taking the neighbour's consent if you plan on installing a camera in the shared space.
For example, the use of CCTV cameras is allowed in public places without the consent of individuals, as long as the cameras are not pointed at areas where there is a reasonable expectation of privacy, such as washrooms or changing rooms.

Thank You										
									 
									
									It is illegal to record audio without the consent of the person being recorded in India. The Information Technology Act, 2000 (IT Act) prohibits the interception, monitoring, decryption, recording or preservation of any communication without the consent of the person concerned.
In your case, your neighbour has installed a CCTV camera with audio recording in the common passage area between your two flats. This camera is recording all conversations you have with your contacts. This is a clear violation of your privacy and is illegal under the IT Act.

headline: Suggestion needee for loan repayment
data:
My loans EMI has surpassed my salary and becoming tough to survive. Hence from now onwards will intentionally bounce my EMIs.

Need expert advise on this how to deal with this.									
									 
									
									Dear Sir,
Remedies against harassment by Recovery Agents
Written By : Kishan Dutt Kalaskar Retired Judge

There are numerous cases of the oppressive and illegal conduct of recovery agents attempting to recover pending dues for the banks' benefit. In the past few years there have been many such instances, to showcase an example, an 81-year-old woman was seriously threatened by recovery agents, she got 375 threatening calls concerning her child's unpaid bank dues. After that, she moved to the police, and a case was filed against these agents. Another incident quoted as per media reports stated that a private bus was halted, and 42 travellers were held hostage for three hours by recovery agents, who needed to recover money from the travel company that owned the bus. These cases affirm that recovery agents/offices are feared in India.   A recovery agent seeks clients and organizations that owe instalments to banks. Many of these recovery agents collect the banks'clientspayment dues for a charge or a percentage of the total amount owed. These agents are generally a third-party

https://www.legalserviceindia.com/legal/article-4865-remedies-against-harassment-by-recovery-agents.html

You may get issue a strong legal notice from my office or file a Suit for Permanent Injunction against Recovery Agents and Bankers. 

 ICCI Bank Limited vs. Prakash Kaur case,

The Supreme Court in a landmark judgement  reiterated its earlier stand that banks cannot deploy musclemen for recovery of loans from defaulters thus forcing them to end their lives.
     
"We deem it appropriate to remind the banks and other financial institutions that we live in a civilised country and are governed by the rule of law," a bench comprising Justices Tarun Chatterjee and Dalveer Bhandari said.
     
The court while dismissing the ICICI Bank's plea refused to delete the Delhi High Court's remarks that held the bank and its musclemen responsible for abetting a youth to commit suicide by humiliating him and taking away his motorcycle financed by the largest private sector bank.
     
It also asked the ICICI Bank to to pay Rs 25,000 as cost of this litigation to the respondents within three weeks and directed the Delhi Police to conclude the investigation against the bank expeditiously within three months, keeping in view the gravity of the allegations.
     
The court also directed the concerned Deputy Commissioner of Police to submit the investigation report in the Delhi High Court.
     
According to the court, complaints received by Reserve Bank regarding violation of the above guidelines and adoption of abusive practices followed by banks recovery agents would be viewed seriously.
     
Reiterating the RBI Guidelines on Engagement of Recovery Agents, the court said, "The Reserve Bank may consider imposing a ban on a bank from engaging recovery agents in a particular area, either jurisdictional or functional, for a limited period. In case of persistent breach of above guidelines, Reserve Bank may consider extending the period of ban or the area of ban."
     
"RBI had expressed its concern about the number of litigations filed against the banks in the recent past for engaging recovery agents who have purportedly violated the law," Justice Bhandari, writing the verdict for the bench, stated.
     
RBI in a letter accompanying its April 24, 2008 Guidelines had stated that it might consider imposing a ban on a bank from engaging recovery agents in a particular area, either jurisdictional or functional, for a limited period.
     
ICICI Bank had moved the apex court seeking deletion of some paragraphs in the High Court order which had said that "...the proximate cause of death of the deceased that led him to commit suicide was on account of humiliation caused by the Bank people from where loan was taken by him."
     
"The modus-operandi employed by the banks like ICICI for realisation of their loan amount and for recovering the possession of the vehicle against which loans are given is extra legal and by no stretch of imagination they can be permitted to employ musclemen and goons for recovery of their dues even from a defaulting party," the High Court had observed.
     
The High Court order had come on a petition filed by Shanti Devi Sharma, the deceased's mother, seeking a probe against the ICICI bank and its staff for the unlawful action, which led to the suicide of her 34-year old son Himanshu Dev Sharma.
     
Sharma had committed suicide in October 2005 by hanging himself at his house after he was allegedly intimidated and humiliated in front of his neighbours and family by recovery agents employed by the bank for recovering the loan amount taken for his motorcycle.
     
The ICICI Bank had contended that it was within its rights to recover loans and had followed the required procedure for recovering dues.
Keep these rules in mind while facing a loan recovery agent
Know the facts
Banks may have an in-house collection department or they may outsource the job to a third-party collection agency. Keep in mind that no bank likes non-performing assets, or bad debts, on their balance sheet. A debt becomes bad when it’s not paid for three consecutive months.
“Usually if the debt is unpaid for a month, the collection team sends reminders or calls up the customer for recovery. However, the delay in payment could just be an oversight on the borrower’s part,” said a senior banker with a private sector bank, who did not want to be named. “But when the debt becomes 90 days overdue, we initiate recovery agent visits.”
This, however, depends on a bank’s policy.
In case you are unable to repay on time, it’s best to tell the bank about your situation. If you have a genuine reason, the bank may be willing to work towards a solution. This also depends on the bank’s policy.
“A credit card debt can be easily converted into an EMI instead of total loan outstanding amount,” said the senior banker cited above. “The bank may even restructure a loan in some cases. Of course, this also depends on your past payment record.”
Handling agents
Keep in mind that at times recovery agents have big targets to achieve and may also have incentives linked to the number and volume of collection. So they are a motivated lot and handling them isn’t easy.
Know the rules: You, as a debtor, have certain rights. Knowing those rights will help you handle a recovery agent.
Identity: You can ask the recover agents to show their identity cards issued by the bank or under the authority of the bank.
Privacy: You have a right to privacy. The recovery agent cannot discuss the debt to another person. So don’t panic if he threatens to tell neighbours or co-workers about your debt. If he does so, you can file a complaint against him with the bank.
Time: The recovery agent should contact you between 7am and 7pm. However, if your working hours or work shift does not permit this, you may be contacted beyond this time limit.
Calls: You can choose the place and time for receiving recovery calls. You can also request them to not call you at a particular place or time. For instance, if you don’t want to receive calls at work, specify the same to the agent or the bank. Keep in mind, they will respect your request only till they feel you are not avoiding them.
Decency: The recovery agent has to talk to you in a decent and civilized manner. No abusive language should be used. Also, the written communication sent by the banks should be easy to understand.
Investigation: If you file a complaint against a recovery agent, the bank needs to investigate the matter. This makes recovery agents accountable for their collection practice.
Inappropriate occasions: If there is a death in your family or any such event, you can tell the agent not to call you or make visits for a few days.
Records: Banks document the content of conversations between customers and agents along with the time and number of calls. Banks also need to keep all copies of communications sent to customers.
Disputes: If you face any dispute or differences regarding dues, seek assistance of the lender.
Seeking help
There could be various reasons for you not being able to pay instalments on time— medical conditions, job loss or a twin-income family becoming a single-income household. Macroeconomic factors such as high inflation or rising interest rates, too, can be the reasons. If the reason for non-payment is not temporary, it’s best is to approach credit counselling agencies and seek help. “We provide free credit counselling for those who are struggling to get out of debt,” said Narayanan Raja, chief executive, BCSBI.
Debt counselling agencies such as Abhay and Disha also offer such services for free. If you are uncomfortable going to these centres, you can avail counselling over telephone which also is provided without any cost.
Recourse if harassed
If you think the agent is not following any of the above mentioned rules, you should file a complaint. Raja said, “If a borrower thinks he is being harassed, he should first approach the bank, and if not satisfied by its response, he should get in touch with the banking ombudsman.”
Though rules have been laid down to assist borrowers, it is best to rework household budget and make provisions to accommodate the unseen change in the repayment amount.
The bank can sue you on defaulting the credit card payment. It cannot amount to criminal liability as it would be considered as non payment of loan which will constitute as a civil act by nature.
The Banks and Financial Institutions can lend money even without security, normally, the Banks and Financial Institutions insist for security for the repayment of loan. The fixed assets, receivables etc. can be securities acceptable to the Banks and Financial Institutions for sanctioning the loans. The loan entitlements, the procedure for sanctioning the loan, the security issues etc, are exclusively governed by the guidelines/norms issued by the Reserve Bank of India.
Loan being an agreement or understanding between the Bank and the borrower, the general laws like Law of Contract, Transfer of Property Act, Specific Relief Act, Specific Performance etc., are applicable to all banking transactions depending upon the nature of transaction. When a borrower fails to repay the money to the Bank, what the Bank can do for recovering the loan is to file a civil suit earlier.
in India the remedy available to lenders has been to file an ordinary money suit for recovery against the defaulting borrower for the outstanding amounts or to file a summary suit as provided for under Order 37 of Code of Civil Procedure 1908

Karnataka HC Asks Registries To Accept Vakalatnama Of New Advocates, Without Insisting On NOC From Previous Ones [Read Order]...

									The court is correct in saying that there should be a respondent in a suit for declaration of the validity of a registered adoption deed. This is because a declaration is a judicial act that declares the existence or non-existence of a legal right or relationship. In order for the court to make such a declaration, there must be someone who is challenging the validity of the adoption deed. This person is the respondent.
In your case, the respondent could be the biological parents of the adopted child, or any other person who has an interest in challenging the validity of the adoption deed. If there is no respondent, then the court cannot make a declaration on the validity of the adoption deed.
The following are some possible solutions 
You could try to contact the biological parents of the adopted child and ask them to consent to the adoption. If they consent, then you will not need to name them as respondents in your suit.
You could try to find another person who has an interest in challenging the validity of the adoption deed and name them as the respondent.
You could try to amend your suit to include a prayer for a declaration that the adoption deed is valid and legal, even without a respondent. However, the court may not grant this prayer.

Yes, divorce is possible within one year of marriage under Section 14 of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955. However, it is only possible if the husband or wife can prove that the other spouse is guilty of one of the following grounds for divorce:
* **Desertion:** The spouse has deserted the other spouse for a continuous period of not less than two years.
* **Cruelty:** The spouse has subjected the other spouse to physical or mental cruelty.
* **Adultery:** The spouse has committed adultery.
* **Unsoundness of mind:** The spouse has been incurably of unsound mind for a continuous period of not less than two years.
* **Conversion to another religion:** The spouse has converted to another religion and does not agree to live with the other spouse according to the Hindu Marriage Act.

The husband or wife must file a petition for divorce in the family court.

No, you cannot get your own other witnesses who are your friends to register your grandparents' will in the sub-registrar's office. The Indian Registration Act, 1908, requires that a will be attested by two witnesses who are present at the same time and who see the testator sign or affix his/her mark on the will. If the original witnesses to your grandparents' will are not contactable, you will need to apply to the court for a probate of the will. Selling price: Rs. 25,00,000
Cost of acquisition: Rs. 17,00,000
Cost of improvement: Nil

									Dear Madam,
Procedure For Filing A Suit/Case
There is a detailed procedure laid down, for filing a civil case. If the procedure is not followed, then the registry has a right to dismiss the suit
The Procedure is as follows:
Filing Of Suit/Plaint
Vakalatnama
Court Fees
How Proceedings Are Conducted
Written Statement
Replication By Plaintiff
Filing Of Other Documents
Framing Of Issues/List Of Witness
Final Hearing
Appeal, Reference And Review
Limitation
Filing of Suit/Plaint
1.	In layman's language plaint is the written complaint/allegation.
2.	One who files it is known as "Plaintiff" and against whom it is filed is known as "Defendant"
3.	The plaint has to be filed within the time limit prescribed in the Limitation Act, and should be typed copy, in double line space.
4.	Name of the Court, Nature of Complaint, Names and Address of parties to be suit has to be clearly mentioned.
5.	Plaint should also contain verification from plaintiff, stating that, contents of the plaint are true and correct
Vakalatnama
1.	A person/party filing a case, May also represent their own case personally in any court.
2.	However, due to lack of knowledge of Law and Technical Procedures, Lawyers are engaged to report the interest of parties.
3.	" Vakalatnama", is a document, by which the party filing the case authorises the Advocate to represent on their behalf?
4.	On General Terms, a Vakalatnama may contain the falling terms:
5.	The client will not hold the Advocate responsible for any decision.
6.	The client shall bear all the costs and/expenses incurred during the proceedings.
7.	The advocate shall have right to retain the documents, unless complete fees are paid.
8.	The client is free to disengage the Advocate at any stage of the Proceedings.
9.	The Advocate shall have all the right to take decisions on his own in the court of Law, during the hearing, to the best interest of client.
10.	Vakalatnama is affixed on the last page of plaint/suit and is kept alongwith court records.
11.	No fees are required to be paid on it. However, nowadays, Delhi High court Rules require, a 10 Rupees. "Advocate Welfare Stamp" to be affixed on the Vakalatnama.
12.	Plaint should also have the requisite court fees attached to it. Court fees are some nominal percentage of the value of the claim or value of the suit. The requisite amount of Court and stamp fees is different for every suit, and is mentioned in the "Court Fees Stamp Act."
Court Fees
Different amount of court fees is paid for different type of documents.
 
Some of them are as follows;
1.	In case of plaint/written statement == 10 RS. == if the value of the suit exceed Rs.5,000/- upto 10,000/-
2.	Plaint , in a suit for possession == Fee of one half of the amount above.
3.	On a copy of a Decree or order == ( 50 paise ) == if the amount or value of Having the force of a decree the subject matter of the suit wherein such decree or order is made is fifty or less than fifty rupees.
Vvalue of Suit
1.	Value of suit exceeds Rs. 1,50,000-1,55,000 == Rs. 1700/-
2.	Value of suit exceeds Rs. 3,00,000-3,05,000 == Rs. 2450/-
3.	Value of suit exceeds Rs. 4,00,000-4,05,000 == Rs. 2950/-
Finally, a date shall be given to the plaintiff, for first hearing. On such hearing, the court will decide whether the proceedings should continue or not. If it decides, that the case no merits, then it will dismiss it there itself, without calling opposite party. If it decides otherwise, then proceedings shall being
How Proceedings Are Conducted
1.	On the first day of hearing, if the court thinks there are merits in the case, it will issue notice to the opposite party, to submit their arguments, and fix a date.
2.	On issuance of notice to the opposite party, the plaintiff is required to do the following:
i.	File requisite amount of procedure--- fee in the court.
ii.	File 2 copies of plaint for each defendant in the court, i.e. if there are 3 defendants, 6 copies has to be filed.
iii.	Of, the 2 copies for each defendant, one shall be sent by Register/post/courier, and one by Ordinary post.
iv.	Such filing should be done within 7 days, from date of order/notice.
Written Statement
1.	When the notice has been issued to the defendant, he is required to appear on the date mentioned in the notice.
2.	Before such date, the defendant is required to file his "written statement", i.e. his defense against the allegation raised by plaintiff, within 30 days from date of service of notice, or within such time as given by court
3.	The written statement should specifically deny the allegations, which defendant thinks are false. Any allegation not specifically denied is deemed to be admitted.
4.	The written statement should also contain verification from the Defendant, stating that, the contents of written statement are true and correct.
5.	The time period of 30 days, for filing a Written Statement, can be extended to 90 days after seeking permission of the court.
Replication By Plaintiff
1.	"Replication" is a reply, filed by the plaintiff, against the "written statement" of Defendant.
2.	"Replication" should also specifically deny the allegations raised by the Defendant in written statement. Anything not denied is deemed to be accepted.
3.	Replication should also contain, a " verification" from the plaintiff, stating that contents of "Replication" are true and correct.
4.	Once Replication is filed, pleadings are stated to be complete.
Filing of Other Documents
1.	Once, the pleadings are complete, then both the parties are given opportunity to produce and file documents, on which they rely, and to substantiate their claims.
2.	Any document not filed or produced cannot be relied upon, during final arguments.
3.	Filing of Documents is not sufficient. They should be admitted and taken on record. In brief the procedure is as follows:
i.	Documents filed by one party may be admitted by opposite party.
ii.	If they are denied by opposite party, then they can be admitted by the witness produced by party whose documents are denied.
iii.	Once the document has been admitted it shall form a part of the record of court, and all the details of suit such as name of parties, title of suit etc, shall be inscribed on the document. (O13 R49 7)
iv.	Documents, which are rejected i.e. not admitted, are returned to the respective parties.
v.	It is necessary that document should be filed in "original", and a spare copy should be given to the opposite party.
Framing of Issues/List of Witness
1.	"ISSUES" are framed by the court, on the basis of which arguments and examination of witness takes place.
2.	Issues are framed, keeping in view the disputes in the suit, and the parties are not allowed to go outside the purview of "Issues".
3.	Issues may be of: A) Fact or B) Law
4.	While passing final order, the court will deal with each issue separately, and pass judgement on each issue.
LIST OF WITNESS
1.	Whichever witness, the parties wish to produce, and to be examined, has to be produced before the court.
2.	Both the parties to the suit shall file a list of witness within 15 days from the date on which issues were framed or within such other period as the court may prescribe.
3.	The parties may either call the witness on it's own, or ask the court to send summons to them.
4.	In case court send summons to witness then the party calling for such witness has to deposit money ' with the Court for their expenses, known as "Diet Money".
5.	A person, who does not appear before the court, if he is required by the court to do so, then the court may impose fine and penalty on him.
6.	Finally on the date, the witness will be examined by both the parties.
i.	Examination by party of it's own witness is called "Examination-in-chief"
ii.	Examination by party of other party's witness is called "cross Examination".
iii.	Whatever, has to be deposed in " Examination-in-chief", can also be filed by way of an Affidavit.
iv.	Once, the Examination and Cross- Examination of witness is over, and also the admission and denial of documents, then the court will fix a date for final hearing.
Final Hearing
1.	On the day fixed for final hearing, the arguments shall take place.
2.	The arguments should strictly be confined to the issues framed.
3.	Before the final Arguments, the parties with the permission of Court, can amend their pleadings.
4.	Whatever is not contained in the pleadings, the court may refuse to listen.
5.	Finally, the court shall pass a "final Order", either on the day of hearing itself, or some other day fixed by the court.
CERTIFIED COPY OF ORDER
1.	Certified copy of order, mean, the final order of court, and having the seal and stamp of court.
2.	Certified copy of useful, in case of execution of the order, or in case of Appeal.
3.	Certified copy can be applied by making an application to the Registry of concerned Court, alongwith nominal fees for the order.
4.	In case of "urgent requirement some additional amount has to be deposited.
5.	"Urgent order" can be obtained within a week, and the normal might take 15 days.
Appeal, Reference and Review
When an order is passed against a party to the suit, it is not that it has no further remedy.
 
Such party can further initiate the proceedings, by way of:
1.	Appeal,
2.	Reference, or
3.	Review.
In brief, the technicalities and difference between these are as follows:

APPEAL
APPEAL FROM ORIGINAL DECREES
(Sec.96)-  	In general, an appeal lies from any decree passed by the   court.
(Sec 96)	In cases, where the value of suit does not exceed  Rs.10, 000 An appeal can be filed only on a question of law.
(Sec.96)	When a decree has been passed against the Defendant as "Ex-Parte", i.e. without his appearance, no appeal is allowed 
(Sec.96) 	When an appeal is headed by two or more judges, then the
majority decision shall prevail.
	In case there is no majority, then the decree of lower court
shall be confirmed.
	In case, the number of judges in the court, where appeal is filed is more, than the number of judges hearing the appeal, then if there is a dispute on a point of law, such dispute can be referred to one or more judges.
 
PROCEDURE FOR APPEAL FROM ORIGINAL DECREES ( ORDER 41)
1.	The appeal shall be filed in the form prescribed, singed by the appellant, alongwith a true certified copy of the order.
2.	The appeal shall contain the grounds of objection under distinct heads, and such grounds shall be numbered consecutively.
3.	If the appeal is against a decree for payment of money, the court may require the appellant to deposit the disputed amount or furnish any other security.
4.	A ground/objection which has not been mentioned in the appeal, cannot be taken up for arguments, without the permission of court.
5.	Similarly any point of act which was not taken up y the Appellant, in lower court, cannot be taken up in appeal lies only against only those points which have been decided by the court rightly or wrongly.
Limitation
1.	For every appeal, there is a limited period, within which appeal should be filed. Such a limitation is provided under the Limitation Act, 1963.
2.	For appeal, in case of a decree passed by lower court in civil suit, the limitation is:
i.	Appeal to High Court- 90 days from the date of decree or order.
ii.	Appeal to any other court- 30 days from the date of Decree or order.
3.	In case there are more than one plaintiffs or defendants, then any one of them can file on appeal against all of them respectively.
4.	Merely because an appeal is filed, does not mean that the order or decree of lower court is stayed. In case of temporary stay of decree or order, it has to be specifically asked, and stay will operate only if court grants it.
5.	In case of execution of decree, the court, which passed the decree, can itself stay the execution for time being on sufficient reasons shown.
6.	The court may require the appellant to deposit some sort of security.
7.	The appellate court may, on the day fixed for hearing the appellant dismiss the appeal, or issue notice to the opposite party to appear on next day.
8.	If on the first day of hearing, appellate court issues summons to the opposite party, then:
i.	It shall fix a date for next hearing, and such date shall be published in the court house.
ii.	Notice shall also be sent to the lower court, whose decree or order has been appealed.
iii.	To appellant is required to file " Process Fee " which is very nominal in amount, and on such filing, the notice shall also be sent to opposite party.
iv.	In case of appeal, the one who files the appeal is known as appellant, and against whom it is filed, is known as "Respondent".

headline: Can I file criminal defamation against Investigating Officer
data:
Sir,

In the year 2021, our neighbour filed an application U/S 156(3) Cr.P.C against me and my mother which was absolutely false and as per the direction of the ACJM, concerned Police Station registered an F.I.R against us U/S 323,354,379, 506,120(B), 34 IPC. Thereafter, we voluntarily surrendered before the ACJM Court with a prayer for bail and our bail was allowed. Subsequently, Charge-Sheet was filed U/S 323,354,506,34 IPC. We perused the application U/S 156(3) wherein it was stated by our neighbour that the alleged incident took place on 05.05.2021 and it was also stated therein that she lodged a complaint before the concerned Police Station by Post on the basis of the said alleged incident date but police did not take action. 

Subsequently, we filed RTI application before the concerned police department, seeking certified copy of her police complaint which was lodged prior to filing 156(3) and finally we got the copy of such police complaint. After perusal of such police complaint, we got extremely surprised and shocked that the De-facto complainant in that police complaint stated that the alleged incident took place on 02.06.2023. The alleged incident date in the application U/S 156(3) and police complaint are absolutely different. 

Immediately thereafter, we filed an application before the ACJM Court, seeking discharge from this case as it was absolutely false and fictitious. Notice was served upon De-facto to attend the hearing of discharge application but on the date of hearing, she did not attend. The ACJM heard our submission and the Public Prosecutor and finally on 04.07.2023 the ACJM has been pleased to pass the final order, discharging us from this case. The observations made that the charges are groundless and no prima facie case is made out against us. 

Now I would like to know that since we have been discharged from this case, so, can I file criminal defamation case against the De-facto complainant i.e. our neighbour for our false implication in this case ? and can I also file it against the Investigating Officer who did not investigate the case in a proper and fair manner and using his legal power two innocent persons were put in the Charge-Sheet. 

Some Ld. Lawyers have told me that I can proceed against the De-facto complainant only by filing criminal defamation but not against the Investigating Officer. So, is it true that I can take action against the De-facto only ? is there no remedy to take action against the Investigating Officer, for whom we were implicated in this case unnecessarily since a long-time. Please tell me the remedy. 


Thank You. 									
									 
									
									Yes, you can file a criminal defamation case against the de facto complainant for falsely implicating you in a criminal case. You can also file a complaint against the investigating officer for not conducting a fair investigation and causing you unnecessary harassment.
The remedy for action against the investigating officer would depend on the specific facts of your case. You may be able to file a complaint with the police or the State Human Rights Commission. You may also be able to file a civil suit for damages.
It is important to consult with a lawyer to discuss your specific case and to get advice on the best course of action.

Here are some of the laws that you may be able to rely on to file a case against the de facto complainant and the investigating officer:

Section 499 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) - Defamation
Section 196 of the IPC - Giving false information to a public servant with intent to cause injury
Section 211 of the IPC - False charge of an offence
Section 154 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) - Power of police to investigate
Section 177 of the CrPC - Duties of investigating officer										
									 
									
									You can proceed against complainant only, not against police.

Kindly revert with exact procedure.									
									 
									
									File a petition with the court. You will need to file a petition with the court, requesting that your biological father's name be changed to your step father's name. The petition should include the following information:
Your name and date of birth
The name of your biological father
The name of your step father
The reason for the name change
The names of any witnesses who can attest to the change

Attend a hearing. The court will hold a hearing to consider your petition. At the hearing, you will need to testify about the reasons for the name change. Your step father may also testify.

headline: What can Criminal Court do if minor witness is not present
data:
Sir,

In 2021, our neighbour filed a false FIR against me and my mother U/S 325, 354B, 504, 506, 34 IPC. We obtained anticipatory bail and thereafter, Charge Sheet filed under the aforesaid sections. On each and every date we remained present before the Trial Court without fail but despite summons, complainant, his mother, his wife and his son (minor) are not being present in Court on any date. On the strength of non bailable warrant issued by Trial Court, complainant, his mother and his wife were arrested and forwarded them to the Court and ultimately their evidence was recorded and they were discharged. 

But now the only problem is that complainant's son is not appearing in Court despite receiving summons. The said son is the minor witness. The Trial Court ordered that the guardian will produce such minor witness, even despite such direction, minor witness is not present. 
Sir I know that Court can not issue warrant against minor witness but what is the remedy to secure the presence of such minor witness ? Because everytime, Court issues fresh summons upon such minor witness and minor witness receives summons and the on the date fixed he is being absent in Court. This game is going on since a long-time. Can Court issue warrant against his guardian i.e. the complainant ? Does the Court have such power ? If so, then under which section of Cr.P.C ? Pls Pls tell me. 									
									 
									
									Pray to court to close the evidence of minor witness, and move on the matter on merits.										
									 
									
									Technically court cannot issue warrant against guardian for non production of witness who is minor. Court can issue warrant. 										
									 
									
									The Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) does not specifically mention the power of the court to issue a warrant against the guardian of a minor witness. However, there are a few sections of the CrPC that could be interpreted to allow the court to do so.

Section 160 of the CrPC allows the court to issue a warrant for the arrest of any person who fails to appear before the court after being summoned. This section does not specifically mention minors, but it could be interpreted to include them.

Section 162 of the CrPC allows the court to take the evidence of a minor witness in camera. This section also allows the court to order that the minor witness be produced in the court by their guardian.

Based on these sections, it could be argued that the court has the power to issue a warrant against the guardian of a minor witness who fails to produce the minor witness in court. However, it is important to note that there is no clear precedent on this issue.

If you are concerned about the non-appearance of the minor witness, you should speak to your lawyer. They will be able to advise you on the best course of action, and they may be able to file a petition with the court requesting that the guardian of the minor witness be ordered to produce the minor witness in court.

Adv. Sarika Khude
Rajgurunagar Pune										
									 
									
									Dear Client,
The Section 118 of the Indian Evidence Act states that all persons, including a child or an aged, are competent to testify unless the court considers that they are prevented from understanding the questions put to them, or from giving rational answers to those questions, by tender years, extreme old age, disease – whether of body or mind – or any other similar cause.

Anyone who fails to appear in court after being summoned may be arrested under Section 160 of the Criminal Procedure Code. Minors may be included even though this section does not directly mention them.

The court may hear a minor witness' testimony in secret under Section 162 of the Criminal Procedure Code. The court may also order that the minor witness be brought before it by their guardian under this clause.


Thank You

Section 65B of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872, provides for the admissibility of electronic records as evidence. Under this section, an electronic record can be admitted as evidence if it is accompanied by a certificate signed by a gazetted officer or a person authorized by the court. The certificate must state that the electronic record is a true copy of the original record and that it has been produced in the manner specified in the section.
In the case of the wife's affidavit, the certificate under Section 65B is not essential for the admissibility of the evidence. If the court does not accept the affidavit without the certificate, the wife's advocate can try to obtain the certificate from the appropriate authority.
If the court does not accept your affidavit, you can appeal the decision. You can also file a motion with the court to reconsider its decision. In your appeal or motion, you should explain why the court should accept your affidavit. You should also address any concerns that the court may have about the admissibility of the affidavit. 195. Prosecution for contempt of lawful authority of public servants, for offences against public justice and for offences relating to documents given in evidence.

(a) (i) of any offence punishable under sections 172 to 188 (both inclusive) of the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860 ), or

The offences under the Section 195 of IPC have been categorized as Bailable offences. A bailable offence is those crimes or offences which are less serious in nature, in such cases bail is a right and the arrested person shall be released after depositing the bail with the police.
