									Based on your description, it seems you are seeking to initiate proceedings under Section 340 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) for what you believe to be false statements or perjury committed by the petitioner.

Section 340 of the CrPC is used when it is alleged that an offense affecting the administration of justice has been committed. This could include false evidence and offenses against public justice, as per the sections mentioned in Section 195(1)(b) of the CrPC.

These sections (193 to 196, 199, 200, 205 to 211, and 228 of the Indian Penal Code) refer to offenses such as giving false evidence, fabricating false evidence, using evidence known to be false, false statements made in declaration which is by law receivable as evidence, etc.

As per Section 195 of the CrPC, cognizance of such offenses can be taken only on a complaint in writing from the court before which the offense was allegedly committed. This is where Section 340 comes in. Section 340 provides a procedure for the court to make a complaint regarding such offenses.

In the context of your question, there is no requirement that the person who made the false claim must be a public servant. If it can be established that false evidence was given by any person in a judicial proceeding, then it is possible to invoke Section 340 of the CrPC.

Going for a GPA (General Power of Attorney) is generally not considered as safe or legally solid as an outright purchase because a GPA does not give you ownership rights, only possession rights. The original owner can still legally sell the property. You may lose your token amount if you decide to back out, depending on the terms of your agreement.
1a) If you decide to go for a GPA, make sure it is properly registered. It should be clearly stated in the GPA that it is irrevocable. Ensure that the GPA specifically mentions your right to construct a house on the property and sell it. However, remember that a GPA can't stop the seller or his legal heirs from selling the property unless it's explicitly mentioned and legally binding.

1b) A registered GPA should reflect in the Encumbrance Certificate, but this can vary based on regional laws and practices.

1c) If the GPA is explicitly stated to be irrevocable, the seller cannot cancel it unilaterally. However, this depends on the exact terms of the GPA and local laws.

Waiting for the government decision is a personal decision based on your risk tolerance and how much you value the land.
2a) If you decide to give more money, an MOU (Memorandum of Understanding) can provide additional protection. A notarized MOU has legal standing but is not as strong as a registered document.

As for other ways to buy the land, you could consider setting up a joint venture with the owner or buying a share in the owner's company if it's a company-owned land. Consult with a legal professional for more options.
Please note that this advice is based on the legal understanding up to 2021 and there may have been changes since. Always consult a legal professional for the most accurate advice.

It actually goes against the Well settled principle of REASONABLE TIME as per the Hon Supreme court judgement in Nekkanti Ramalakshmi vs State of Karnataka and also goes against Doctrine of Unreasonable delay when the provisions of the Statute is invoked after an inordinate delay of 25 years. 									Dear Client,
In the run-up to the Assembly polls, the Congress had promised to amend the PTCL Act. Dalit groups have been demanding the removal of the time bar for claims on lands that were originally granted to them but were subsequently sold or taken over by others.
The Karnataka Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes Prohibition of Transfer of Certain Lands (Amendment) Bill, 2023 was tabled in the state legislature on July 19 after a special Cabinet meeting. The Congress had promised to amend the law in the run-up to the Assembly polls.
On July 7, during his Budget speech, Chief Minister Siddaramaiah had stated that he was intent on amending the PTCL Act. “In order to enable SC/ST land grantees to appeal for restoration of land, suitable amendments will be made to the Karnataka Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prohibition of Transfer of Certain Lands) Act, 1978 by prescribing timeline in the Act itself,” he had stated.

However, such amendment cannot be inconsistent with the provision of the Constitution or cause unreasonable and irreparable loss to the public.
Reasonable time period and fixed time period are two distinct interpretations.
Fixed time limit is governed by the law of limitation, where time limit is prescribed and none can be allowed to breach the limitation, unless courts condone the delay, which means that the court has discretionary power to extend the limitation period in certain situation to ensure end of justice.
Whereas, the reasonable time means a fair time limit under which the aggrieved party can approach the court, when no specific time limit has been mentioned.
25 years is not a reasonable time limit, but an unreasonable delay, which violates the Law of Equity, which speaks that" law supports only those who are agile for their rights and not those who are sleeping".

Protection under Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 (IDA):
The Industrial Disputes Act provides protection to employees against wrongful termination or dismissal. If the employer coerces an employee into resigning, it may be treated as a "retrenchment" under the IDA, and the employee could be entitled to certain protections and benefits.
Constructive Dismissal:
In India, constructive dismissal occurs when the employer makes working conditions so unbearable that the employee is forced to resign. If an employee can establish that the resignation was a result of the employer's actions, it could be treated as a case of constructive dismissal.
Protection under labor contracts:
Employment contracts, whether written or oral, govern the terms of employment. If an employer is violating the terms of the employment contract, the employee may have legal recourse.

Maternity Benefit Act, 1961:
If an employer is forcing a female employee to resign due to pregnancy or maternity-related issues, it could be a violation of the Maternity Benefit Act, which provides protection to female employees during pregnancy and maternity leave.

Equal Remuneration Act, 1976:
The Equal Remuneration Act prohibits discrimination in remuneration on the basis of gender. If the employer is forcing an employee to resign based on gender, it could be a violation of this act.

Section 12 in The Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
12. Duties of conciliation officers.- (relevant section 12(2) of ID Act)

(1) Where any industrial dispute exists or is apprehended, the conciliation officer may, or where the dispute relates to a public utility service and a notice under section 22 has been given, shall hold conciliation proceedings in the prescribed manner.

(2) The conciliation officer shall, for the purpose of bringing about a settlement of the dispute, without delay, investigate the dispute and all matters affecting the merits and the right settlement thereof and may do all such things as he thinks fit for the purpose of inducing the parties to come to a fair and amicable settlement of the dispute.

(3) If a settlement of the dispute or of any of the matters in dispute is arrived at in the course of the conciliation proceedings the conciliationofficer shall send a report thereof to the appropriate Government 1 or an officer authorised in this behalf by the appropriate Government] together with a memorandum of the settlement signed by the parties to the dispute.

(4) If no such settlement is arrived at, the conciliation officer shall, as soon as practicable after the close of the investigation, send to the appropriate Government a full report setting forth the steps taken by him for ascertaining the facts and circumstances relating to the dispute and for bringing about a settlement thereof, together with a full statement of such facts and circumstances, and the reasons on account of which, in his opinion, a settlement could not be arrived at.

(5) If, on a consideration of the report referred to in sub- section (4), the appropriate Government is satisfied that there is a case for reference to a Board, 2 Labour Court, Tribunal or National Tribunal,] it may make such reference. Where the appropriate Government does not make such a reference it shall record and communicate to the parties concerned its reasons therefor.

(6) A report under this section shall be submitted within fourteen days of the commencement of the conciliation proceedings or within such shorter period as may be fixed by the appropriate Government: 3 Provided that, 4 subject to the approval of the conciliation officer,] the time for the submission of the report may be extended by such period as may be agreed upon in writing by all the parties to the dispute.]

									The likelihood of a final order (decision) being in favor of a party can vary based on several factors and the specific circumstances of the case. Interim orders are temporary decisions made by the court to address immediate issues until the final judgment is delivered. The final order may or may not align with the interim order, as the court will consider all the evidence, arguments, and legal principles before reaching a final decision.

Factors that may influence the final order include:

    Strength of Evidence: The evidence presented by both parties during the trial can significantly impact the final decision. Strong and convincing evidence may sway the court in favor of one party.

    Legal Arguments: The legal arguments made by the parties and their legal representatives will be evaluated by the court. The strength of these arguments and their alignment with applicable laws can influence the final decision.

    Case Precedents: Previous court decisions in similar cases (case precedents) can influence the final judgment, as courts often refer to these precedents to guide their decisions.

    Witness Testimonies: Credible witness testimonies can play a crucial role in supporting a party's claims and influencing the final outcome.

    Judges' Discretion: Judges have the discretion to make decisions based on their interpretation of the law and the facts presented in the case.

    Changed Circumstances: If there are significant changes in the circumstances of the case between the time of the interim order and the final judgment, it may impact the outcome.

It's essential to remember that every case is unique, and predicting the exact outcome of a legal proceeding is challenging. The final order will be based on a thorough evaluation of all the evidence and legal arguments presented during the trial. It's crucial to have proper legal representation and ensure that all relevant evidence and arguments are effectively presented to maximize the chances of a favorable final order.

headline: Bailable warrant executed in one case be considered in another caseS
data:
Sub : Bailable warrant executed in one case be considered in another cases, when issued in one transaction
Supreme Court of India’s 5 Judges Bench in a case named
In Re Expeditious Trial Of Cases ... vs On 11.10.2020 Which Was ... on 16 April, 2021 held as under:
24. 5) The High Courts are requested to issue practice directions to the Trial Courts to treat service of
summons in one complaint under Section 138 forming part of a transaction, as deemed service in
respect of all the complaints filed before the same court relating to dishonour of cheques issued as
part of the said transaction.
Please guide whether same will be applicable on Bailabale Warrants  also. In our case u/s 138 N I Act against Partnership Firm and its 3 Partners,  5 cases were lodged as there were 5 instalments cheques issued against one loan taken,  summons were sent through Registered AD deemed to be served. Afterwards Bailable Warrants were issued in all 5 cases, against all three Partners. 
In one case, all three partners got bail after executing Bailable Warrant upon them.
But in remaining 4 cases, one partner is dodging the Police. So on every hearing, no further proceedings were held , two remain absent with Haziri Maphi and on one  till date, bailable warrant could not be executed.
When the attention of above citation alongh with another citation of Supreme court Vani Agro Enterprises vs The State Of Gujarat on 5 September, 2019 was brought to the Presiding Officer, she simple looked at them and returned them. 
So please guide what is the law 1.whether bailable warrant executed in one case, can not be considered as executed in 4 other case as per above citation .
2. Any other citation or ruling which say valuable time of Court and police should be saved and warrant executed in one case should be considered in other cases also which arose from the same transaction.
3. Any other remedy in addition to that in every case bailable warrant should be executed on all.
									
									 
									
									1.	There is significant distinction between purpose of a BB, NBW and summons. There are different modes in which a summons can be served on accused like, through paper publication, affixing summons on his house etc. but a BB or NBW requires execution on accused. Therefore, law laid down by SC is not applicable to BB and NBWs. 
2.	There is no such authority. 
3.	File a petition under Section 72 and 73 seeking appointment of Advocate/Commissioner for execution of BB against accused. Court will appoint such Advocate/Commissioner and issue direction to local police to assist him. Take a police and Advocate/Commissioner, point the accused to police, he will execute the BB in presence of Advocate/Commissioner and produce him in Court.

headline: Meaning of international law
data:
What does international law means and how exactly does it work 									
									 
									
									There is no statutory international law as such customs convention  make international law										
									 
									
									Dear Client,
International law is the set of rules, norms, and standards generally recognised as binding between states. It establishes normative guidelines and a common conceptual framework for states across a broad range of domains, including war and diplomacy, economic relations, and human rights.
International law is not a single, unified body of law. It is made up of a variety of sources, including:
Customary international law.
Treaties.
General principles of law.
Judicial decisions.
International law is a complex and ever-evolving body of law. It plays an important role in regulating the behavior of states and in promoting peace and security around the world.
Here are some examples of how international law works:
The United Nations Charter is an international treaty that sets out the principles and purposes of the United Nations. It is a binding source of international law that all UN member states are required to comply with.
The Geneva Conventions are a set of international treaties that protect the victims of war. They set out rules on the treatment of prisoners of war, the wounded and sick, and civilians in times of war.
The Universal Declaration of Human Rights is a non-binding declaration that sets out the fundamental human rights of all people. It has been influential in shaping the development of international human rights law.
Hope now you are aware about International law.
Thank you.

If a daughter secretly did registered marriage, does her father or guardian search it in West Bengal?

									Yes, a daughter's father or guardian can search for her registered marriage in West Bengal. The Special Marriage Act, 1954, which governs registered marriages in India, does not require the consent of parents or guardians for a person to get married. However, the marriage must be registered with the Registrar of Marriages in the district where it is solemnized. The registration certificate will be issued to the couple and will be a public document. This means that anyone can search for it on the Registrar of Marriages' website.

In your specific case, if your daughter secretly got married in West Bengal, her father or guardian could search for the marriage registration on the Registrar of Marriages' website. If they find the registration, they will be able to see the date of the marriage, the names of the couple, and the place where the marriage was solemnized.

It is important to note that even if a marriage is registered, it does not necessarily mean that it is valid. For example, if the couple was not of legal age to get married, or if they were not mentally competent to give their consent, the marriage could be declared invalid. If you are concerned about the validity of your daughter's marriage, you should consult with an attorney.

Here are some additional things to keep in mind:

The Special Marriage Act does not require that a registered marriage be solemnized in a religious ceremony. However, many couples choose to have a religious ceremony in addition to the civil registration.
If a couple is married under the Special Marriage Act, they are not required to live together. However, if they do live together, they will be considered to be legally married.
A registered marriage under the Special Marriage Act is not automatically dissolved if the couple gets divorced under religious law. If the couple wants to dissolve their marriage, they will need to file for divorce under the Special Marriage Act.

									Dear Client,
Yes, the APP can cross-examine you when you produce documents from your side. The APP has the right to cross-examine any witness, including a witness who is producing documents. The APP can cross-examine you on the documents that you produce, as well as on any other relevant matters.
Section 139 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states that a person who is summoned to produce a document does not become a witness unless he is asked to be a witness in the matter. This means that if you are summoned to produce a document in a criminal case, you will not be cross-examined unless you are asked to be a witness.
Section 146 of the Indian Evidence Act states that the cross-examination of a witness may relate to any matter relevant to the issue in the case, or to the credibility of the witness. This means that the APP can cross-examine you on the documents that you produce, as well as on any other relevant matters, such as your knowledge of the documents, the circumstances in which you came to possess the documents, and the accuracy of the documents.

headline: WHICH ACT APPLICABLE FOR SHOP OWNERS ASSOCIATION IN W.B.

									Dear Client,
A group of shop owners as well as shop tenants would register their association under the West Bengal Societies Registration Act, 1961. The Cooperative Societies Act is only applicable to societies that are formed for the promotion of economic interests of its members. In Haryana, the Ground Water Act, 1991 is applicable for regulating groundwater extraction and usage. 451. Order for custody and disposal of property pending trial in certain cases. When any property is produced before any Criminal Court during any inquiry or trial, the Court may make such order as it thinks fit for the proper custody of such property pending the conclusion of the inquiry or trial, and, if the property is subject to speedy and natural decay, or if it is otherwise expedient so to do, the Court may, after recording such evidence as it thinks necessary, order it to be sold or otherwise disposed of. Explanation.- For the purposes of this section," property" includes-
(a) property of any kind or document which is produced before the Court or which is in its custody,
(b) any property regarding which an offence appears to have been committed or which appears to have been used for the commission of any offence.

Section 340(1) CrPC

Whenever an application is filed before a court by a public servant or affected party, a preliminary inquiry should be made before appearing in the court, if the court is of the opinion that it is expedient in nature for the administration of justice.

One should file under Section 340 of the CrPC when there is true evidence and a falsely deposed statement against that.
The court, after conducting such preliminary inquiry, can record a finding on that aspect; can make a complaint thereof if the court is of the opinion that the offence has been committed for which the application was filed; send the case to the Magistrate having first class jurisdiction, wherever the jurisdiction of the offence lies (the place where the offence was committed); can take sufficient security from the accused for the purpose of the appearance of the accused and can send the accused under the custody of the concerned magistrate; any person can be bound to appear in court and give pieces of evidence.
